  <verse number="38" style="v" />As for the younger daughter, she also gave birth to a son, and named him Ben Ammi. He became the ancestor of the people of Ammon of today.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Abraham journeyed from there toward the land of the Negev, and lived between Kadesh and Shur. He was a foreigner living in Gerar.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Abraham said concerning Sarah his wife, "She is my sister." So Abimelech king of Gerar sent his men and they took Sarah.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />But God came to Abimelech in a dream in the night, and said to him, "Behold, you are a dead man because of the woman whom you have taken, for she is a man's wife."

<verse number="4" style="v" />Now Abimelech had not come near her and he said, "Lord, would you kill even a righteous nation?

  <verse number="5" style="v" />Did he not himself say to me, 'She is my sister?' Even she herself said, 'He is my brother.' I have done this in the integrity of my heart and the innocence of my hands."

<verse number="6" style="v" />Then God said to him in the dream, "Yes, I also know that in the integrity of your heart you did this, and I also kept you from sinning against me. Therefore I did not allow you to touch her.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />Therefore, return the man's wife, for he is a prophet. He will pray for you, and you will live. But if you do not restore her, know that you and all who are yours will surely die."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Abimelech rose early in the morning and called all of his servants to himself. He told all these things to them, and the men were very afraid.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Then Abimelech called for Abraham and said to him, "What have you done to us? How have I sinned against you, that you have brought on me and on my kingdom a great sin? You have done to me that which ought not to be done."

<verse number="10" style="v" />Abimelech said to Abraham, "What prompted you to do this thing?"

  <verse number="11" style="v" />Abraham said, "Because I thought, 'Surely there is no fear of God in this place, and they will kill me because of my wife.'

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Besides, she is indeed my sister, the daughter of my father, but not the daughter of my mother; and she became my wife.

<verse number="13" style="v" />When God caused me to leave my father's house and travel from place to place, I said to her, 'You must show me this faithfulness as my wife: At every place where we go, say about me, "He is my brother."'"

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Then Abimelech took sheep and oxen, and male and female slaves, and gave them to Abraham. Then he returned Sarah, Abraham's wife, to him.

<verse number="15" style="v" />Abimelech said, "Look, my land is before you. Settle wherever it pleases you."

  <verse number="16" style="v" />To Sarah he said, "Look, I have given your brother a thousand pieces of silver. It is to cover any offense against you in the eyes of all that are with you, and before everyone, you are completely made right."

<verse number="17" style="v" />Then Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelech, his wife, and his female slaves so that they were able to have children.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />For Yahweh had caused all the women of the household of Abimelech to be completely infertile, because of Sarah, Abraham's wife.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Yahweh paid attention to Sarah as he had said he would, and Yahweh did for Sarah just as he had promised.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Sarah conceived and bore a son to Abraham in his old age, at the set time of which God had spoken to him.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Abraham named his son, the one who had been born to him, whom Sarah bore to him, Isaac.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />Abraham circumcised his son Isaac when he was eight days old, just as God had commanded him.

<verse number="5" style="v" />Abraham was one hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Sarah said, "God has made me laugh; every one who hears will laugh with me."

  <verse number="7" style="v" />She also said, "Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children, and yet I have borne him a son in his old age!"</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="8" style="v" />The child grew and was weaned, and Abraham made a great feast on the day that Isaac was weaned.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian, whom she had borne to Abraham, mocking.

<verse number="10" style="v" />So she said to Abraham, "Drive out this slave woman and her son: for the son of this slave woman will not be heir with my son, with Isaac."

  <verse number="11" style="v" />This thing was very grievous to Abraham because of his son.

<verse number="12" style="v" />But God said to Abraham, "Do not be grieved because of the lad, and because of your servant woman. Listen to her words in all she says to you about this matter, because it is through Isaac that your descendants will be named.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />I will also make the son of the servant woman into a nation, because he is your descendant."

<verse number="14" style="v" />Abraham rose up early in the morning, took bread and a skin of water, and gave it to Hagar, putting it on her shoulder. He gave her the boy and sent her away. She departed and wandered in the wilderness of Beersheba.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />When the water in the waterskin was gone, she abandoned the child under one of the bushes.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Then she went, and sat down a short distance from him, about the distance of a bowshot away, for she said, "Let me not look upon the death of the child." As she sat there across from him, she lifted up her voice and wept.

<verse number="17" style="v" />God heard the voice of the lad, and the angel of God called to Hagar out of heaven, and said to her, "What troubles you, Hagar? Do not be afraid, for God has heard the voice of the lad where he is.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Get up, raise up the lad, and encourage him; for I will make him into a great nation."

<verse number="19" style="v" />Then God opened her eyes, and she saw a well of water. She went and filled the skin with water, and gave the lad a drink.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />God was with the lad, and he grew. He lived in the wilderness and became an archer.

  <verse number="21" style="v" />He lived in the wilderness of Paran, and his mother got a wife for him from the land of Egypt.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="22" style="v" />It came about at that time that Abimelech and Phicol the captain of his army spoke to Abraham, saying, "God is with you in all that you do.

  <verse number="23" style="v" />Now therefore swear to me here by God that you will not deal falsely with me, nor with my children, nor with my descendants. Show to me and to the land in which you have been staying the same covenant faithfulness that I have shown to you."

  <verse number="24" style="v" />Abraham said, "I swear."

<verse number="25" style="v" />Abraham also complained to Abimelech concerning a well of water that Abimelech's servants had seized from him.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />Abimelech said, "I do not know who has done this thing. You did not tell me before now; I have not heard of it until today."

  <verse number="27" style="v" />So Abraham took sheep and oxen and gave them to Abimelech, and the two men made a covenant.

<verse number="28" style="v" />Then Abraham set seven female lambs of the flock by themselves.

  <verse number="29" style="v" />Abimelech said to Abraham, "What is the meaning of these seven female lambs that you have set by themselves?"

  <verse number="30" style="v" />He replied, "These seven female lambs you will receive from my hand, so that it may be a witness for me, that I dug this well."

<verse number="31" style="v" />So he called that place Beersheba, because there they both swore an oath.

  <verse number="32" style="v" />They made a covenant at Beersheba, and then Abimelech and Phicol, the captain of his army, returned to the land of the Philistines.

<verse number="33" style="v" />Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beersheba. There he worshiped Yahweh, the eternal God.

  <verse number="34" style="v" />Abraham remained as a foreigner in the land of the Philistines many days.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />It came about after these things that God tested Abraham. He said to him, "Abraham!" Abraham said, "Here I am."

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Then God said, "Take your son, your only son, whom you love, Isaac, and go to the land of Moriah. Offer him there as a burnt offering upon one of the mountains there, which I will tell you about."

  <verse number="3" style="v" />So Abraham rose early in the morning, saddled his donkey, and took two of his young men with him, along with Isaac his son. He cut the wood for the burnt offering, then set out on his journey to the place that God had told him about.

<verse number="4" style="v" />On the third day Abraham looked up and saw the place afar off.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />Abraham said to his young men, "Stay here with the donkey, and I and the lad will go over there. We will worship and come again to you."

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Then Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and put it on Isaac his son. He took in his own hand the fire and the knife; and they went both of them together.

<verse number="7" style="v" />Isaac spoke to Abraham his father and said, "My father," and he said, "Here I am, my son." He said, "See, here is the fire and the wood, but where is the lamb for the burnt offering?"

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Abraham said, "God himself will provide the lamb for the burnt offering, my son." So they went on, both of them together.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="9" style="v" />When they came to the place that God had told him about, Abraham built an altar there and laid the wood on it. Then he bound Isaac his son, and laid him on the altar, on top of the wood.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />Abraham reached out with his hand and took up the knife to kill his son.

<verse number="11" style="v" />Then the angel of Yahweh called to him from heaven and said, "Abraham, Abraham!" and he said, "Here I am."

  <verse number="12" style="v" />He said, "Do not lay your hand upon the lad, nor do anything to harm him, for now I know that you fear God, seeing that you have not withheld your son, your only son, from me."

<verse number="13" style="v" />Abraham looked up and behold, behind him was a ram caught in the bushes by his horns. Abraham went and took the ram and offered him up as a burnt offering instead of his son.

  <verse number="14" style="v" />So Abraham called that place, "Yahweh will provide," and it is said to this day, "On the mountain of Yahweh it will be provided."

<verse number="15" style="v" />The angel of Yahweh called to Abraham a second time from heaven

  <verse number="16" style="v" />and said—this is an oracle of Yahweh, "By myself I have sworn that because you have done this thing, and have not withheld your son, your only son,

  <verse number="17" style="v" />I will surely bless you and I will greatly multiply your descendants as the stars of the heavens, and as the sand which is upon the seashore; and your descendants will possess the gate of their enemies.

<verse number="18" style="v" />Through your offspring all the nations of the earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed my voice."

  <verse number="19" style="v" />So Abraham returned to his young men, and they departed and went together to Beersheba, and he lived at Beersheba.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="20" style="v" />It came about after these things that Abraham was told, "Milcah has borne children, as well, to your brother Nahor."

  <verse number="21" style="v" />They were Uz his firstborn, Buz his brother, Kemuel the father of Aram,

  <verse number="22" style="v" />Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.

<verse number="23" style="v" />Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. These were the eight children that Milcah bore to Nahor, Abraham's brother.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />His concubine, whose name was Reumah, also bore Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Sarah lived a hundred and twenty-seven years. These were the years of the life of Sarah.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Sarah died in Kiriath Arba, that is, Hebron, in the land of Canaan. Abraham mourned and wept for Sarah.

<verse number="3" style="v" />Then Abraham rose up and went from his dead wife, and spoke to the sons of Heth, saying,

  <verse number="4" style="v" />"I am a foreigner among you. Please grant me a property for a burial place among you, so that I may bury my dead."

<verse number="5" style="v" />The sons of Heth answered Abraham, saying,

  <verse number="6" style="v" />"Listen to us, my master. You are a prince of God among us. Bury your dead in the choicest of our tombs. None of us will refuse you his tomb, so that you may bury your dead."

<verse number="7" style="v" />Abraham arose and bowed down to the people of the land, to the sons of Heth.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />He spoke to them, saying, "If you agree that I should bury my dead, then hear me and plead with Ephron son of Zohar, for me.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Ask him to sell me the cave of Machpelah, which he owns, which is at the end of his field. For the full price let him sell it to me publicly as a property for a burial place."

<verse number="10" style="v" />Now Ephron was sitting among the sons of Heth, and Ephron the Hittite answered Abraham in the hearing of the sons of Heth, of all those who had come into the gate of his city, saying,

  <verse number="11" style="v" />"No, my master, hear me. I give you the field, and the cave that is in it. I give it to you in the presence of the sons of my people. I give it to you to bury your dead."

<verse number="12" style="v" />Then Abraham bowed himself down before the people of the land.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />He spoke to Ephron in the hearing of the people of the land, saying, "But if you are willing, please hear me. I will pay for the field. Take the money from me, and I will bury my dead there."

<verse number="14" style="v" />Ephron answered Abraham, saying,

  <verse number="15" style="v" />"Please, my master, listen to me. A piece of land worth four hundred shekels of silver, what is that between me and you? Bury your dead."

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Abraham listened to Ephron and Abraham weighed out to Ephron the amount of silver that he had spoken in the hearing of the sons of Heth, four hundred shekels of silver, according to the standard measurement of the merchants.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="17" style="v" />So the field of Ephron, which was in Machpelah, which was next to Mamre, that is, the field, the cave that was in it, and all the trees that were in the field and all around its border, passed

  <verse number="18" style="v" />to Abraham by purchase in the presence of the sons of Heth, before all those who had come into the gate of his city.

<verse number="19" style="v" />After this, Abraham buried Sarah his wife in the cave of the field of Machpelah, which is next to Mamre, that is, Hebron, in the land of Canaan.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />So the field and the cave in it passed to Abraham as a property for a burial place from the sons of Heth.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Now Abraham was old, well advanced in years, and Yahweh had blessed Abraham in all things.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Abraham said to his servant, the one who was the oldest of his household and who was in charge of all that he had, "Put your hand under my thigh

  <verse number="3" style="v" />and I will make you swear by Yahweh, the God of heaven and the God of the earth, that you will not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I make my home.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />But you will go to my country, and to my relatives, and get a wife for my son Isaac."

<verse number="5" style="v" />The servant said to him, "What if the woman will not be willing to follow me to this land? Must I take your son back to the land from which you came?"

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Abraham said to him, "Make sure that you do not take my son back there!

  <verse number="7" style="v" />Yahweh, the God of heaven, who took me from my father's house and from the land of my relatives, and who promised me with a solemn oath saying, 'To your offspring I will give this land,' he will send his angel before you, and you will get a wife for my son from there.

<verse number="8" style="v" />But if the woman is not willing to follow you, then you will be free from this oath of mine. Only you are not to take my son back there."

  <verse number="9" style="v" />So the servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master, and swore to him concerning this matter.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="10" style="v" />The servant took ten of his master's camels and departed. He also took with him all kinds of gifts from his master. He departed and went to the region of Aram Naharaim, to the city of Nahor.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />He made the camels kneel down outside the city by the well of water. It was evening, the time that women go out to draw water.

<verse number="12" style="v" />Then he said, "Yahweh, God of my master Abraham, grant me success today and show covenant faithfulness to my master Abraham.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Look, here I am standing by the spring of water, and the daughters of the men of the city are coming out to draw water.

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Let it happen like this. When I say to a young woman, 'Please lower your pitcher so that I may drink,' and she says to me, 'Drink, and I will water your camels too,' then let her be the one that you have appointed for your servant Isaac. By this I will know that you have shown covenant faithfulness to my master."

<verse number="15" style="v" />It came about that even before he had finished speaking, behold, Rebekah came out with her water pitcher on her shoulder. Rebekah was born to Bethuel son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor, Abraham's brother.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />The young woman was very beautiful and a virgin. No man had slept with her. She went down to the spring and filled her pitcher, and came up.

<verse number="17" style="v" />Then the servant ran to meet her and said, "Please give me a little drink of water from your pitcher."

  <verse number="18" style="v" />She said, "Drink, my master," and she quickly let down her pitcher on her hand, and gave him a drink.

<verse number="19" style="v" />When she had finished giving him a drink, she said, "I will draw water for your camels also, until they have finished drinking."

  <verse number="20" style="v" />So she hurried and emptied her pitcher into the trough, then ran again to the well to draw water, and drew water for all his camels.

<verse number="21" style="v" />The man watched her in silence to see whether Yahweh had prospered his journey or not.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />As the camels finished drinking, the man brought out a gold nose ring weighing half a shekel, and two gold bracelets for her arms weighing ten shekels,

  <verse number="23" style="v" />and asked, "Whose daughter are you? Tell me please, is there room in your father's house for us to spend the night?"

<verse number="24" style="v" />She said to him, "I am the daughter of Bethuel son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor."

  <verse number="25" style="v" />She also said to him, "We have plenty of both straw and feed, and also room for you to spend the night."

<verse number="26" style="v" />Then the man bowed down and worshiped Yahweh.

  <verse number="27" style="v" />He said, "Blessed be Yahweh, the God of my master Abraham, who has not forsaken his covenant faithfulness and his trustworthiness toward my master. As for me, Yahweh has led me directly to the house of my master's relatives."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="28" style="v" />Then the young woman ran and told her mother's household about all of these things.

  <verse number="29" style="v" />Now Rebekah had a brother, and his name was Laban. Laban ran to the man who was out at the road by the spring.

  <verse number="30" style="v" />When he had seen the nose ring and the bracelets on his sister's arms, and when he had heard the words of Rebekah his sister, "This is what the man said to me," he went to the man, and, behold, he was standing by the camels at the spring.

<verse number="31" style="v" />And Laban said, "Come, you blessed of Yahweh. Why are you standing outside? I have prepared the house, and a place for the camels."

  <verse number="32" style="v" />So the man came to the house and he unloaded the camels. The camels were given straw and feed, and water was provided to wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.

<verse number="33" style="v" />They set food before him to eat, but he said, "I will not eat until I have said what I have to say." So Laban said, "Speak on."

  <verse number="34" style="v" />He said, "I am Abraham's servant.

  <verse number="35" style="v" />Yahweh has blessed my master very much and he has become great. He has given him flocks and herds, silver and gold, male servants and female servants, and camels and donkeys.

<verse number="36" style="v" />Sarah, my master's wife, bore a son to my master when she was old, and he has given everything that he owns to him.

  <verse number="37" style="v" />My master made me swear, saying, 'You must not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I make my home.

  <verse number="38" style="v" />Instead, you must go to my father's family, and to my relatives, and get a wife for my son.'

<verse number="39" style="v" />I said to my master, 'Perhaps the woman will not follow me.'

  <verse number="40" style="v" />But he said to me, 'Yahweh, before whom I walk, will send his angel with you and he will prosper your way, so that you will get a wife for my son from among my relatives and from my father's family line.

  <verse number="41" style="v" />But you will be free from my oath if you come to my relatives and they will not give her to you. Then you will be free from my oath.'

<verse number="42" style="v" />So I arrived today at the spring, and said, 'O Yahweh, God of my master Abraham, please, if you do indeed intend to make my journey successful—

  <verse number="43" style="v" />here I am, standing by the spring of water—let the young woman who comes out to draw water, the woman to whom I say, "Please give me a little water from your pitcher to drink,"

  <verse number="44" style="v" />the woman who says to me, "Drink, and I will also draw water for your camels"—let her be the woman whom you, Yahweh, have chosen for my master's son.'

<verse number="45" style="v" />Even before I had finished speaking in my heart, behold, Rebekah came out with her pitcher on her shoulder and she went down to the spring and drew water. So I said to her, 'Please give me a drink.'

  <verse number="46" style="v" />She quickly lowered her pitcher from her shoulder and said, 'Drink, and I will give your camels water also.' So I drank, and she watered the camels also.

<verse number="47" style="v" />I asked her and said, 'Whose daughter are you?' She said, 'The daughter of Bethuel, Nahor's son, whom Milcah bore to him.' Then I put the ring in her nose and the bracelets on her arms.

  <verse number="48" style="v" />Then I bowed down and worshiped Yahweh, and blessed Yahweh, the God of my master Abraham, who had led me by the right way to find the daughter of my master's relative for his son.

<verse number="49" style="v" />Now therefore, if you are prepared to treat my master with family faithfulness and trustworthiness, tell me. But if not, tell me, so that I may turn to the right hand, or to the left."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="50" style="v" />Then Laban and Bethuel answered and said, "The thing has come from Yahweh; we cannot speak to you either bad or good.

  <verse number="51" style="v" />Look, Rebekah is before you. Take her and go, so she may be the wife of your master's son, as Yahweh has spoken."

<verse number="52" style="v" />When Abraham's servant heard their words, he bowed himself down to the ground to Yahweh.

  <verse number="53" style="v" />The servant brought out articles of silver and articles of gold, and clothing, and gave them to Rebekah. He also gave precious gifts to her brother and to her mother.

<verse number="54" style="v" />Then he and the men who were with him ate and drank. They stayed there overnight, and when they arose in the morning, he said, "Send me away to my master."

  <verse number="55" style="v" />Her brother and her mother said, "Let the young woman stay with us for a few more days, at least ten. After that she may go."

<verse number="56" style="v" />But he said to them, "Do not hinder me, since Yahweh has prospered my way. Send me on my way so that I may go to my master."

  <verse number="57" style="v" />They said, "We will call the young woman and ask her."

  <verse number="58" style="v" />So they called Rebekah and asked her, "Will you go with this man?" She replied, "I will go."

<verse number="59" style="v" />So they sent their sister Rebekah, along with her female servant, on her journey with Abraham's servant and his men.

  <verse number="60" style="v" />They blessed Rebekah, and said to her, </para>

<para style="q1">"Our sister, may you be the mother of thousands of ten thousands, </para>

<para style="q1">and may your descendants possess the gate of those who hate them."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="61" style="v" />Then Rebekah arose, and she and her servant girls mounted the camels, and followed the man. Thus the servant took Rebekah, and went his way.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="62" style="v" />Now Isaac was living in the Negev, and had just returned from Beerlahairoi.

<verse number="63" style="v" />Isaac went out to meditate in the field in the evening. When he looked up and saw, behold, there were camels coming!

  <verse number="64" style="v" />Rebekah looked, and when she saw Isaac, she jumped down from the camel.

  <verse number="65" style="v" />She said to the servant, "Who is that man who is walking in the field to meet us?" The servant said, "It is my master." So she took her veil, and covered herself.

<verse number="66" style="v" />The servant recounted to Isaac all the things that he had done.

  <verse number="67" style="v" />Then Isaac brought her into his mother Sarah's tent and took Rebekah, and she became his wife, and he loved her. So Isaac was comforted after his mother's death.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Abraham took another wife; her name was Keturah.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />She bore him Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Jokshan became the father of Sheba and Dedan. The descendants of Dedan were the Assyrian people, the Letush people, and the Leum people.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />Midian's sons were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were Keturah's descendants.

<verse number="5" style="v" />Abraham gave all that he owned to Isaac.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />However, while he was still living, he gave gifts to the sons of his concubines and sent them to the land of the east, away from Isaac, his son.

<verse number="7" style="v" />These were the days of the years of Abraham's life which he lived, 175 years.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Abraham breathed his last and died at a good old age, an old man with a full life, and he was gathered to his people.

<verse number="9" style="v" />Isaac and Ishmael, his sons, buried him in the cave of Machpelah, in the field of Ephron son of Zohar the Hittite, which is near Mamre.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />This field Abraham had bought from the sons of Heth. Abraham was buried there with Sarah his wife.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />After the death of Abraham, God blessed Isaac his son, and Isaac lived near Beerlahairoi.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Now these were the descendants of Ishmael, Abraham's son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah's servant, bore to Abraham.

<verse number="13" style="v" />These were the names of Ishmael's sons, according to their birth order: Nebaioth—the firstborn of Ishmael, Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Mishma, Dumah, Massa,

  <verse number="15" style="v" />Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />These were Ishmael's sons, and these were their names, by their villages, and by their encampments; twelve princes according to their tribes.

<verse number="17" style="v" />These were the years of the life of Ishmael, 137 years: he breathed his last and died, and was gathered to his people.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />They lived from Havilah to Shur, which is near Egypt, as one goes toward Assyria. They lived in hostility with each other.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="19" style="v" />These were the events concerning Isaac, Abraham's son: Abraham became the father of Isaac.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />Isaac was forty years old when he took as his wife Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel the Aramean of Paddan Aram, the sister of Laban the Aramean.

<verse number="21" style="v" />Isaac prayed to Yahweh for his wife because she was childless, and Yahweh answered his prayer, and Rebekah his wife conceived.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />The children struggled together within her, and she said, "Why is this happening to me?" She went to ask Yahweh about this.

<verse number="23" style="v" />Yahweh said to her,</para>

<para style="q1">"Two nations are in your womb, and two peoples will be separated from within you.</para>

<para style="q1">One people will be stronger than the other, and the older will serve the younger."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="24" style="v" />When it was time for her to give birth, behold, there were twins in her womb.

  <verse number="25" style="v" />And the first came out red all over like a hairy garment. They called his name Esau.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />After that, his brother came out. His hand was grasping Esau's heel. He was called Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when his wife bore them.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="27" style="v" />The boys grew up, and Esau became a skillful hunter, a man of the field; but Jacob was a quiet man, who spent his time in the tents.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />Now Isaac loved Esau because he ate the animals that he had hunted, but Rebekah loved Jacob.

<verse number="29" style="v" />Jacob cooked some stew. Esau came in from the field, and he was weak from hunger.

  <verse number="30" style="v" />Esau said to Jacob, "Feed me with that red stew. Please, I am exhausted!" That is why was his name was called Edom.

<verse number="31" style="v" />Jacob said, "First sell me your birthright."

  <verse number="32" style="v" />Esau said, "Look, I am about to die. What good is the birthright to me?"

  <verse number="33" style="v" />Jacob said, "First swear to me," so Esau swore an oath and in that way he sold his birthright to Jacob.

  <verse number="34" style="v" />Jacob gave Esau bread and stew of lentils. He ate and drank, then got up and went on his way. In this manner Esau despised his birthright.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Now a famine happened in the land, besides the first famine that had been in the days of Abraham. Isaac went to Abimelech, king of the Philistines at Gerar.

<verse number="2" style="v" />Now Yahweh appeared to him and said, "Do not go down to Egypt; live in the land that I tell you to live in.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Stay in this very land, and I will be with you and will bless you; for to you and to your descendants, I will give allthese lands, and I will fulfill the oath that I swore to Abraham your father.

<verse number="4" style="v" />I will multiply your descendants like the stars of heaven, and will give to your descendants all these lands. Through your descendants all the nations of the earth will be blessed.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />I will do this because Abraham obeyed my voice and kept my instructions, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws."

<verse number="6" style="v" />So Isaac settled in Gerar.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />When the men of the place asked him about his wife, he said, "She is my sister." He feared to say, "She is my wife," because he thought, "The men of this place will kill me to get Rebekah, because she is so beautiful."

  <verse number="8" style="v" />After Isaac had been there a long time, Abimelech king of the Philistines happened to look out of a window. He saw, behold, Isaac was caressing Rebekah, his wife.

<verse number="9" style="v" />Abimelech called Isaac to him and said, "Look, certainly she is your wife. Why did you say, 'She is my sister'?" Isaac said to him, "Because I thought someone might kill me to get her."

  <verse number="10" style="v" />Abimelech said, "What is this you have done to us? One of the people might easily have slept with your wife, and you would have brought guilt upon us."

  <verse number="11" style="v" />So Abimelech warned all the people and said, "Whoever touches this man or his wife will surely be put to death."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Isaac planted crops in that land and reaped in the same year a hundredfold, because Yahweh blessed him.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />The man became rich, and grew more and more until he became very great.

  <verse number="14" style="v" />He had many sheep and cattle, and a large household. The Philistines envied him.

<verse number="15" style="v" />Now all the wells that his father's servants had dug in the days of Abraham his father, the Philistines stopped them up by filling them with earth.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Abimelech said to Isaac, "Go away from us, for you are much mightier than we."

  <verse number="17" style="v" />So Isaac departed from there and settled in the valley of Gerar, and lived there.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Once again Isaac dug out the wells of water, which they had dug in the days of Abraham his father. The Philistines had stopped them up after Abraham's death. Isaac called the wells by the same names that his father had called them.

<verse number="19" style="v" />When Isaac's servants dug in the valley, they found there a well of flowing water.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />The herdsmen of Gerar quarreled with Isaac's herdsmen, and said, "This water is ours." So Isaac called that well "Esek," because they had quarreled with him.

<verse number="21" style="v" />Then they dug another well, and they quarreled over that, too, so he gave it the name of "Sitnah."

  <verse number="22" style="v" />He left there and dug yet another well, but they did not quarrel over that one. So he called it Rehoboth, and he said, "Now Yahweh has made room for us, and we will prosper in the land."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="23" style="v" />Then Isaac went up from there to Beersheba.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />Yahweh appeared to him that same night and said, "I am the God of Abraham your father. Do not fear, for I am with you and will bless you and multiply your descendants, for my servant Abraham's sake."

  <verse number="25" style="v" />Isaac built an altar there and called on the name of Yahweh. There he pitched his tent, and his servants dug a well.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="26" style="v" />Then Abimelech went to him from Gerar, with Ahuzzath, his friend, and Phicol, the captain of his army.

  <verse number="27" style="v" />Isaac said to them, "Why are you coming to me, since you hate me and have sent me away from you?"

<verse number="28" style="v" />And they said, "We have clearly seen that Yahweh has been with you. So we decided that there should be an oath between us, yes, between us and you. So let us make a covenant with you,

  <verse number="29" style="v" />that you will do us no harm, just as we have not harmed you, and as we have treated you well and have sent you away in peace. Indeed, you are blessed by Yahweh."

<verse number="30" style="v" />So Isaac made a feast for them, and they ate and drank.

  <verse number="31" style="v" />They rose early in the morning and swore an oath with each other. Then Isaac sent them away, and they left him in peace.

<verse number="32" style="v" />That same day Isaac's servants came and told him about the well that they had dug. They said, "We have found water."

  <verse number="33" style="v" />He called the well Shibah, so the name of that city is Beersheba to this day.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="34" style="v" />When Esau was forty years old, he took a wife, Judith the daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and also Basemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite.

  <verse number="35" style="v" />They brought sorrow to Isaac and Rebekah.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />When Isaac was old and his eyes were dim so that he could not see, he called Esau, his older son, and said to him, "My son." He said to him, "Here I am."

  <verse number="2" style="v" />He said, "See here, I am old. I do not know the day of my death.

<verse number="3" style="v" />Therefore take your weapons, your quiver and your bow, and go out to the field and hunt game for me.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />Make delicious food for me, the sort that I love, and bring it to me so I can eat it and bless you before I die."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="5" style="v" />Now Rebekah heard it when Isaac spoke to Esau his son. Esau went to the field to hunt for game and bring it back.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Rebekah spoke to Jacob her son and said, "See here, I heard your father speak to Esau your brother. He said,

  <verse number="7" style="v" />'Bring me game and make me delicious food, that I may eat it and bless you in the presence of Yahweh before my death.'

<verse number="8" style="v" />Now therefore, my son, obey my voice as I command you.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Go to the flock, and bring me two good young goats; and I will make delicious food from them for your father, just like he loves.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />You will take it to your father, so that he may eat it, so that he may bless you before his death."

<verse number="11" style="v" />Jacob said to Rebekah his mother, "See, Esau my brother is a hairy man, and I am a smooth man.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Perhaps my father will touch me, and I will seem to him as a deceiver. I will bring a curse upon me and not a blessing."

<verse number="13" style="v" />His mother said to him, "My son, let any curse fall on me. Just obey my voice, and go, bring them to me."

  <verse number="14" style="v" />So Jacob went and got the young goats and brought them to his mother, and his mother made delicious food, just like his father loved.

<verse number="15" style="v" />Rebekah took the best clothes of Esau, her older son, which were with her in the house, and put them on Jacob, her younger son.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />She put the skins of the young goats on his hands and on the smooth part of his neck.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />She put the delicious food and the bread that she had prepared into the hand of her son Jacob.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Jacob went to his father and said, "My father." He said, "Here I am; who are you, my son?"

  <verse number="19" style="v" />Jacob said to his father, "I am Esau your firstborn; I have done as you said to me. Now sit up and eat some of my game, that you may bless me."

<verse number="20" style="v" />Isaac said to his son, "How is it that you have found it so quickly, my son?" He said, "Because Yahweh your God brought it to me."

  <verse number="21" style="v" />Isaac said to Jacob, "Come near me, so I may touch you, my son, and learn whether you are my true son Esau or not."

<verse number="22" style="v" />Jacob went over to Isaac his father; and Isaac touched him and said, "The voice is Jacob's voice, but the hands are the hands of Esau."

  <verse number="23" style="v" />Isaac did not recognize him, because his hands were hairy, like his brother Esau's hands, so Isaac blessed him.

<verse number="24" style="v" />He said, "Are you really my son Esau?" And he said, "I am."

  <verse number="25" style="v" />Isaac said, "Bring the food to me, and I will eat of your game, so that I may bless you." Jacob brought the food to him. Isaac ate, and Jacob brought him wine, and he drank.

<verse number="26" style="v" />Then his father Isaac said to him, "Come near now and kiss me, my son."

  <verse number="27" style="v" />Jacob came near and kissed him, and he smelled the smell of his clothes and blessed him. He said,</para>

<para style="q1">"See, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field that Yahweh has blessed.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="28" style="v" />May God give you a portion of the dew of heaven, a portion of the fatness of the earth,</para>

<para style="q1">and plenty of grain and new wine.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="29" style="v" />May peoples serve you and nations bow down to you.</para>

<para style="q1">Be master over your brothers, and may your mother's sons bow down to you.</para>

<para style="q1">May every one who curses you be cursed; may every one who blesses you be blessed."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="30" style="v" />As soon as Isaac had finished blessing Jacob, and Jacob had scarcely gone out from the presence of Isaac his father, Esau his brother came in from his hunting.

  <verse number="31" style="v" />He also made delicious food and brought it to his father. He said to his father, "Father, get up and eat some of your son's game, so that you may bless me."

<verse number="32" style="v" />Isaac his father said to him, "Who are you?" He said, "I am your son, your firstborn, Esau."

  <verse number="33" style="v" />Isaac trembled very much and said, "Who was it that hunted this game and brought it to me? I ate it all before you came, and I have blessed him. Indeed, he will be blessed."

<verse number="34" style="v" />When Esau heard the words of his father, he cried with a very great and bitter cry, and said to his father, "Bless me, me also, my father."

  <verse number="35" style="v" />Isaac said, "Your brother came here deceitfully and has taken away your blessing."

<verse number="36" style="v" />Esau said, "Is he not rightly named Jacob? For he has cheated me these two times. He took away my birthright, and, see, now he has taken away my blessing." And he said, "Have you not reserved a blessing for me?"

  <verse number="37" style="v" />Isaac answered and said to Esau, "Look, I have made him your master, and I have given to him all his brothers as servants. And I have given him grain and new wine. What more can I do for you, my son?"
<verse number="38" style="v" />Esau said to his father, "Have you not even one blessing for me, my father? Bless me, even me too, my father." Esau wept loudly.

<verse number="39" style="v" />Isaac his father answered and said to him,</para>

<para style="q1">"Look, the place where you live will be far from the richness of the earth,</para>

<para style="q1">away from the dew of the sky above.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="40" style="v" />By your sword you will live, and you will serve your brother.</para>

<para style="q1">But when you rebel, you will shake his yoke from off your neck."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="41" style="v" />Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing that his father had given him. Esau said in his heart, "The days of mourning for my father are near; after that I will kill my brother Jacob."

  <verse number="42" style="v" />The words of Esau her older son were told to Rebekah. So she sent and called Jacob her younger son and said to him, "See, your brother Esau is consoling himself about you by planning to kill you.

<verse number="43" style="v" />Now therefore, my son, obey me and flee to Laban, my brother, in Haran.

  <verse number="44" style="v" />Stay with him for a while, until your brother's fury subsides,

  <verse number="45" style="v" />until your brother's anger turns away from you, and he forgets what you have done to him. Then I will send and bring you back from there. Why should I lose you both in one day?</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="46" style="v" />Rebekah said to Isaac, "I am weary of life because of the daughters of Heth. If Jacob takes one of the daughters of Heth as a wife, like these women, some of the daughters of the land, what good will my life be to me?"</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Isaac called Jacob, blessed him, and commanded him, "You must not take a wife from the Canaanite women.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Arise, go to Paddan Aram, to the house of Bethuel your mother's father, and take a wife from there, one of the daughters of Laban, your mother's brother.

<verse number="3" style="v" />May God Almighty bless you, make you fruitful and multiply you, so that you may become a multitude of peoples.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />May he give you the blessing of Abraham, to you, and to your descendants after you, that you may inherit the land where you have been living, which God gave to Abraham."
<verse number="5" style="v" />So Isaac sent Jacob away. Jacob went to Paddan Aram, to Laban son of Bethuel the Aramean, the brother of Rebekah, Jacob's and Esau's mother.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Now Esau saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob and sent him away to Paddan Aram, to take a wife from there. He also saw that Isaac had blessed him and given him a command, saying, "You must not take a wife from the women of Canaan."

  <verse number="7" style="v" />Esau also saw that Jacob had obeyed his father and his mother, and had gone to Paddan Aram.

<verse number="8" style="v" />Esau saw that the women of Canaan did not please Isaac his father.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />So he went to Ishmael, and took, besides the wives that he had, Mahalath the daughter of Ishmael, Abraham's son, the sister of Nebaioth, to be his wife.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="10" style="v" />Jacob left Beersheba and went toward Haran.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />He came to a certain place and stayed there all night, because the sun had set. He took one of the stones in that place, put it under his head, and lay down in that place to sleep.

<verse number="12" style="v" />He dreamed and saw a stairway set up on the earth. Its top reached to heaven and the angels of God were ascending and descending on it.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Behold, Yahweh stood above it and said, "I am Yahweh, the God of Abraham your father, and the God of Isaac. The land on which you are lying, I will give to you and to your descendants.

<verse number="14" style="v" />Your descendants will be like the dust of the earth, and you will spread far out to the west, to the east, to the north, and to the south. In you and in your descendants will all the families of the earth be blessed.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />Behold, I am with you, and I will keep you wherever you go. I will bring you into this land again; for I will not leave you. I will do all that I have promised to you."

<verse number="16" style="v" />Jacob awoke out of his sleep, and he said, "Surely Yahweh is in this place, and I did not know it."

  <verse number="17" style="v" />He was afraid and said, "How terrifying is this place! This is none other than the house of God. This is the gate of heaven."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Jacob arose early in the morning and took the stone that he had put under his head. He set it up as a pillar and poured oil upon the top of it.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />He called the name of that place Bethel, but the name of the city originally was Luz.

<verse number="20" style="v" />Jacob vowed a vow, saying, "If God will be with me and will protect me on this road on which I am walking, and will give me bread to eat, and clothes to wear,

  <verse number="21" style="v" />so that I return safely to my father's house, then Yahweh will be my God.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />Then this stone that I have set up as a pillar will be a sacred stone. From everything that you give me, I will surely give a tenth back to you."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Then Jacob went on his journey and came to the land of the people of the east.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />As he looked, he saw a well in the field, and, behold, three flocks of sheep were lying there by it. For out of that well they would water the flocks, and the stone over the well's mouth was large.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />When all the flocks had gathered there, the shepherds would roll the stone from the well's mouth and water the sheep, and then put the stone again over the well's mouth, back in its place.

<verse number="4" style="v" />Jacob said to them, "My brothers, where are you from?" And they said, "We are from Haran."

  <verse number="5" style="v" />He said to them, "Do you know Laban son of Nahor?" They said, "We know him."

  <verse number="6" style="v" />He said to them, "Is he well?" They said, "He is well, and, look there, Rachel his daughter is coming with the sheep."

<verse number="7" style="v" />Jacob said, "See, it is the middle of the day. It is not the time for the flocks to be gathered together. You should water the sheep and then go and let them graze."

  <verse number="8" style="v" />They said, "We cannot water them until all the flocks are gathered together. The men will then roll the stone from the well's mouth, and we will water the sheep."

<verse number="9" style="v" />While Jacob was still speaking with them, Rachel came with her father's sheep, for she was tending them.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />When Jacob saw Rachel, the daughter of Laban, his mother's brother, and the sheep of Laban, his mother's brother, Jacob came over, rolled the stone from the well's mouth, and watered the flock of Laban, his mother's brother.

<verse number="11" style="v" />Jacob kissed Rachel and wept loudly.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Jacob told Rachel that he was her father's relative, and that he was Rebekah's son. Then she ran and told her father.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="13" style="v" />When Laban heard the news about Jacob his sister's son, he ran to meet him, embraced him,kissed him, and brought him to his house. Jacob told Laban all these things.

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Laban said to him, "You are indeed my bone and my flesh." Then Jacob stayed with him for about one month.

<verse number="15" style="v" />Then Laban said to Jacob, "Should you serve me for nothing because you are my relative? Tell me, what will your wages be?"

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Now Laban had two daughters. The name of the older was Leah, and the name of the younger was Rachel.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />Leah's eyes were tender, but Rachel was beautiful in form and appearance.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Jacob loved Rachel, so he said, "I will serve you seven years for Rachel, your younger daughter."

<verse number="19" style="v" />Laban said, "It is better that I give her to you, than that I should give her to another man. Stay with me."

  <verse number="20" style="v" />So Jacob served seven years for Rachel; and they seemed to him only a few days, for the love he had for her.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="21" style="v" />Then Jacob said to Laban, "Give me my wife, for my days have been completed—so that I may marry her!"

  <verse number="22" style="v" />So Laban gathered together all the men of the place and made a feast.

<verse number="23" style="v" />In the evening, Laban took Leah his daughter and brought her to Jacob, who slept with her.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />Laban gave his female servant Zilpah to his daughter Leah, to be her servant.

  <verse number="25" style="v" />In the morning, behold, it was Leah! Jacob said to Laban, "What is this you have done to me?Did I not serve you for Rachel? Why then have you tricked me?"

<verse number="26" style="v" />Laban said, "It is not our custom to give the younger daughter before the firstborn.

  <verse number="27" style="v" />Complete the bridal week of this daughter, and we will give you the other also in return for serving me anotherseven years."

<verse number="28" style="v" />Jacob did so, and completed Leah's week. Then Laban gave him Rachel his daughter as his wife also.

  <verse number="29" style="v" />Laban also gave Bilhah to his daughter Rachel, to be her servant.

  <verse number="30" style="v" />So Jacob slept with Rachel, too, but he loved Rachel more than Leah. So Jacob served Laban for seven more years.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="31" style="v" />Yahweh saw that Leah was not loved, so he opened her womb, but Rachel was childless.

  <verse number="32" style="v" />Leah conceived and bore a son, and she called his name Reuben. For she said, "Because Yahweh has looked upon my affliction; surely now my husband will love me."

<verse number="33" style="v" />Then she conceived again and bore a son. She said, "Because Yahweh has heard that I am unloved, he has therefore given me this son also," and she called his name Simeon.

  <verse number="34" style="v" />Then she conceived again and bore a son. She said, "Now this time will my husband be attached to me, because I have borne him three sons." Therefore his name was called Levi.
<verse number="35" style="v" />She conceived again and bore a son. She said, "This time I will praise Yahweh." Therefore she called his name Judah; then she stopped having children.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />When Rachel saw that she bore Jacob no children, Rachel envied her sister. She said to Jacob, "Give me children, or I will die."

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Jacob's anger was burned against Rachel. He said, "Am I in the place of God, who has kept you from having children?"

<verse number="3" style="v" />She said, "See, there is my servant Bilhah. Sleep with her, so she might give birth to children on my knees, and I will have children by her."

  <verse number="4" style="v" />So she gave him her servant Bilhah as a wife, and Jacob slept with her.

<verse number="5" style="v" />Bilhah conceived and bore Jacob a son.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Then Rachel said, "God has judged in my favor. He has listened to my prayer and given me a son." For this reason she called his name Dan.

<verse number="7" style="v" />Bilhah, Rachel's servant, conceived again and bore Jacob a second son.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Rachel said, "With mighty wrestlings have I wrestled with my sister and have prevailed." She called his name Naphtali.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="9" style="v" />When Leah saw that she had stopped having children, she took Zilpah, her servant, and gave her to Jacob as a wife.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />Zilpah, Leah's servant, bore Jacob a son.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />Leah said, "This is fortunate!" so she called his name Gad.

<verse number="12" style="v" />Then Zilpah, Leah's servant, bore Jacob a second son.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Leah said, "I am happy! For the daughters will call me happy." So she called his name Asher.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Reuben went in the days of wheat harvest and found mandrakes in the field. He brought them to his mother Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, "Give me some of your son's mandrakes."

  <verse number="15" style="v" />Leah said to her, "Is it a small matter to you, that you have taken away my husband? Do you now want to take away my son's mandrakes, too?" Rachel said, "Then he will sleep with you tonight, in exchange for your son's mandrakes."

<verse number="16" style="v" />Jacob came from the field in the evening. Leah went out to meet him and said, "You must sleep with me tonight, for I have hired you with my son's mandrakes." So Jacob slept with Leah that night.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />God listened to Leah, and she conceived and bore Jacob a fifth son.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Leah said, "God has given me my wages, because I gave my servant woman to my husband." She called his name Issachar.

<verse number="19" style="v" />Leah conceived again and bore a sixth son to Jacob.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />Leah said, "God has given me a good gift. Now my husband will honor me, because I have borne him six sons." She called his name Zebulun.

  <verse number="21" style="v" />Afterwards she bore a daughter and called her name Dinah.

<verse number="22" style="v" />God called Rachel to mind and listened to her. He caused her to become pregnant.

  <verse number="23" style="v" />She conceived and bore a son. She said, "God has taken away my shame."

  <verse number="24" style="v" />She called his name Joseph, saying, "Yahweh has added to me another son."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="25" style="v" />After Rachel had borne Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, "Send me away, so that I may go to my own home and to my country.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />Give me my wives and my children for whom I have served you, and let me go, for you know the service I have given you."

<verse number="27" style="v" />Laban said to him, "If now I have found favor in your eyes, wait, because I have learned by using divination that Yahweh has blessed me for your sake."

  <verse number="28" style="v" />Then he said, "Name your wages, and I will pay them."

<verse number="29" style="v" />Jacob said to him, "You know how I have served you, and how your livestock have fared with me.

  <verse number="30" style="v" />For you had little before I came, and it has increased abundantly. Yahweh has blessed you wherever I worked. Now when will I provide for my own household also?"

<verse number="31" style="v" />So Laban said, "What will I pay you?" Jacob said, "You will not give me anything. If you will do this thing for me, I will again feed your flock and keep it.

  <verse number="32" style="v" />Let me walk through all your flock today, removing from it every speckled and spotted sheep, and every black one among the sheep, and the spotted and speckled among the goats. These will be my wages.

<verse number="33" style="v" />My integrity will testify for me later on, when you come to check on my wages. Every one that is not speckled and spotted among the goats, and black among the sheep, if any are found with me, will be considered to be stolen."

  <verse number="34" style="v" />Laban said, "Agreed. Let it be according to your word."

<verse number="35" style="v" />That day Laban removed the male goats that were striped and spotted, and all the female goats that were speckled and spotted, every one that had white in it, and all the black ones among the sheep, and gave them into the hand of his sons.

  <verse number="36" style="v" />Laban also put three days' journey between himself and Jacob. So Jacob kept tending the rest of Laban's flocks.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="37" style="v" />Jacob took fresh cut branches of fresh poplar, and of the almond and of the plane tree, and peeled white streaks in them, and made the white inner wood appear that was in the sticks.

  <verse number="38" style="v" />Then he set the sticks that he had peeled in front of the flocks, in front of the watering troughs where they came to drink. They conceived when they came to drink.

<verse number="39" style="v" />The flocks bred in front of the sticks; and the flocks produced striped, speckled, and spotted young.

  <verse number="40" style="v" />Jacob separated out these lambs, but made the rest of them face toward the striped animals and all the black sheep in the flock of Laban. Then he separated out his flocks for himself alone and did not put them together with Laban's flocks.

<verse number="41" style="v" />Whenever the stronger sheep in the flock were breeding, then Jacob would lay the sticks in the watering troughs before the eyes of the flock, so that they might conceive among the sticks.

  <verse number="42" style="v" />But when the feebler animals in the flock came, he did not put the sticks in front of them. So the feebler animals were Laban's, and the stronger were Jacob's.
<verse number="43" style="v" />The man became very prosperous. He had large flocks, female servants and male servants, and camels and donkeys.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Now Jacob heard the words of Laban's sons, that they said, "Jacob has taken away all that was our father's, and it is from our father's possessions that he has gotten all this wealth."

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Jacob saw the look on Laban's face. He saw that his attitude toward him had changed.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Then Yahweh said to Jacob, "Return to the land of your fathers and to your relatives, and I will be with you."

<verse number="4" style="v" />Jacob sent and called Rachel and Leah to the field to his flock

  <verse number="5" style="v" />and said to them, "I see your father's attitude toward me has changed, but the God of my father has been with me.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />You know that it is with all my strength that I have served your father.

<verse number="7" style="v" />Your father has deceived me and changed my wages ten times, but God has not permitted him to hurt me.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />If he said, 'The speckled animals will be your wages,' then all the flock bore speckled young. And if he said, 'The striped will be your wages,' then the whole flock bore striped young.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />In this way God has taken away the livestock of your father and given them to me.

<verse number="10" style="v" />Once at the time of breeding season, I saw in a dream the male goats that were mating with the flock. The male goats were striped, speckled, and spotted.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />The angel of God said to me in the dream, 'Jacob.' I said, 'Here I am.'

<verse number="12" style="v" />He said, 'Lift up your eyes and see all the male goats that are breeding with the flock. They are striped, speckled, and spotted, for I have seen everything that Laban is doing to you.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar, where you made a vow to me. Now rise up and leave this land and return to the land of your birth.'"

<verse number="14" style="v" />Rachel and Leah answered and said to him, "Is there any portion or inheritance for us in our father's house?

  <verse number="15" style="v" />Are we not treated by him as foreigners? For he has sold us and has also completely devoured our money.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />For all the riches that God has taken away from our father are now ours and our children's. Now then, whatever God has said to you, do it."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="17" style="v" />Then Jacob arose and placed his sons and his wives upon the camels.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />He drove all his livestock ahead of him, along with all his property, including the livestock he had acquired in Paddan Aram. Then he set out to go to his father Isaac in the land of Canaan.

<verse number="19" style="v" />When Laban had gone to shear his sheep, Rachel stole her father's household gods.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />Jacob also deceived Laban the Aramean, by not telling him that he was leaving.

  <verse number="21" style="v" />So he fled with all that he had and quickly passed over the River, and headed toward the hill country of Gilead.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="22" style="v" />On the third day Laban was told that Jacob had fled.

  <verse number="23" style="v" />So he took his relatives with him and pursued him for a seven days' journey. He overtook him in the hill country of Gilead.

<verse number="24" style="v" />Now God came to Laban the Aramean in a dream at night and said to him, "Be careful that you speak to Jacob neither good or bad."

  <verse number="25" style="v" />Laban overtook Jacob. Now Jacob had pitched his tent in the hill country. Laban also camped with his relatives in the hill country of Gilead.

<note caller="+" style="f">

  <char style="ft">Some modern versions have: </char>

  <char style="fqa">Laban also camped in the hill country of Gilead. </char>

  <char style="fqb"></char>

</note>

<verse number="26" style="v" />Laban said to Jacob, "What have you done, that you deceived me and carried away my daughters like prisoners of war?

  <verse number="27" style="v" />Why did you flee secretly and trick me and did not tell me. I would have sent you away with celebration and with songs, with tambourine and with harps.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />You did not allow me to kiss my grandsons and my daughters good bye. Now you have done foolishly.

<verse number="29" style="v" />It is in my power to do you harm, but the God of your father spoke to me last night and said, 'Be careful that you speak to Jacob neither good or bad.'

  <verse number="30" style="v" />And now, you have gone away because you longed very much for your father's house. But why have you stolen my gods?"

<verse number="31" style="v" />Jacob answered and said to Laban, "Because I was afraid and thought that you would take your daughters from me by force I left secretly.

  <verse number="32" style="v" />Whoever has stolen your gods will not continue to live. In the presence of our relatives, identify whatever with me is yours and take it." For Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen them.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="33" style="v" />Laban went into Jacob's tent, into Leah's tent, and into the tent of the two female servants, but he did not find them. He went out of Leah's tent and entered into Rachel's tent.

<verse number="34" style="v" />Now Rachel had taken the household gods, put them in a camel's saddle, and sat upon them. Laban searched the whole tent, but did not find them.

  <verse number="35" style="v" />She said to her father, "Do not be angry, my master, that I cannot stand up before you, for I am having my period." So he searched but did not find his household gods.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="36" style="v" />Jacob was angry and argued with Laban. He said to him, "What is my offense? What is my sin, that you have hotly pursued after me?

  <verse number="37" style="v" />For you have searched all my possessions. What have you found of all your household goods? Set them here before our relatives, so that they may judge between us two.

<verse number="38" style="v" />For twenty years I have been with you. Your ewes and your female goats have not miscarried, nor have I eaten any rams from your flocks.

  <verse number="39" style="v" />What was torn by beasts I did not bring to you. Instead, I bore the loss of it. You always made me pay for every missing animal, whether stolen by day or stolen by night.

  <verse number="40" style="v" />There I was; in the day the heat consumed me, and the frost by night; and I went without sleep.

<verse number="41" style="v" />These twenty years I have been in your household. I worked for you fourteen years for your two daughters, and six years for your flock. You have changed my wages ten times.

  <verse number="42" style="v" />Unless the God of my father, the God of Abraham, and the one Isaac fears, had been with me, surely now you would have sent me away empty-handed. God has seen my oppression and how hard I worked, and he rebuked you last night."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="43" style="v" />Laban answered and said to Jacob, "The daughters are my daughters, the grandchildren are my grandchildren, and the flocks are my flocks. All that you see is mine. But what can I do today to these my daughters, or to their children whom they have borne?

  <verse number="44" style="v" />So now, let us make a covenant, you and I, and let it be for a witness between you and me."

<verse number="45" style="v" />So Jacob took a stone and set it up as a pillar.

  <verse number="46" style="v" />Jacob said to his relatives, "Gather stones." So they took stones and made a pile. Then they ate there by the pile.

  <verse number="47" style="v" />Laban called it Jegar Saha Dutha, but Jacob called it Galeed.

<verse number="48" style="v" />Laban said, "This pile is a witness between me and you today." Therefore its name was called Galeed.

  <verse number="49" style="v" />It is also called Mizpah, because Laban said, "May Yahweh watch between you and me, when we are out of sight one from another.

  <verse number="50" style="v" />If you mistreat my daughters, or if you take any wives besides my daughters, although no one else is with us, see, God is witness between you and me."

<verse number="51" style="v" />Laban said to Jacob, "Look at this pile, and look at the pillar, which I have set between you and me.

  <verse number="52" style="v" />This pile is a witness, and the pillar is a witness, that I will not pass beyond this pile to you, and that you will not pass beyond this pile and this pillar to me, to do harm.

  <verse number="53" style="v" />May the God of Abraham, and the God of Nahor, the God of their father, judge between us." Jacob swore by God, him whom his father Isaac feared.

<verse number="54" style="v" />Jacob offered a sacrifice on the mountain and called his relatives to eat a meal. They ate and spent the entire night on the mountain.

  <verse number="55" style="v" />Early in the morning Laban got up, kissed his grandsons and his daughters and blessed them. Then Laban left and returned home. </para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Jacob also went on his way, and the angels of God met him.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />When Jacob saw them, he said, "This is God's camp," so he called the name of that place Mahanaim.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Jacob sent messengers ahead of him to his brother Esau, in the land of Seir, in the region of Edom.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />He commanded them, saying, "This is what you will say to my master Esau: This is what your servant Jacob says: 'I have been staying with Laban, and I have stayed until now.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />I have oxen, donkeys, and flocks, male servants, and female servants.  I have sent to tell this to my master, that I may find favor in your sight.'"

<verse number="6" style="v" />The messengers returned to Jacob and said, "We went to your brother Esau. He is coming to meet you, and four hundred men are with him."

  <verse number="7" style="v" />Then Jacob was very afraid and upset. So he divided the people who were with him into two camps, and also the flocks, the herds, and the camels.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />He said, "If Esau comes to one camp and attacks it, then the camp that is left will escape."

<verse number="9" style="v" />Jacob said, "God of my father Abraham, and God of my father Isaac, Yahweh, who said to me, 'Return to your country and to your kindred, and I will prosper you,'

  <verse number="10" style="v" />I am not worthy of all your acts of covenant faithfulness and of all the trustworthiness that you have done for your servant. For with only my staff I passed over this Jordan, and now I have become two camps.

<verse number="11" style="v" />Please rescue me from the hand of my brother, from the hand of Esau, for I am afraid of him, that he will come and attack me and the mothers with the children.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />But you said, 'I will certainly make you prosper. I will make your descendants like the sand of the sea, which cannot be numbered for their number.'"</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Jacob stayed there that night. He took some of what he had with him as a gift for Esau, his brother:

  <verse number="14" style="v" />two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,

  <verse number="15" style="v" />thirty milking camels and their colts, forty cows and ten bulls, twenty female donkeys and ten male donkeys.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />These he handed over to his servants, every herd by itself. He said to his servants, "Go on ahead of me and put a space between each of the herds."

<verse number="17" style="v" />He instructed the first servant, saying, "When Esau my brother meets you and asks you, saying, 'To whom do you belong? Where are you going? And whose are these animals in front of you?'

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Then you will say, 'They are your servant Jacob's. They are a gift sent to my master Esau. And see, he is also coming after us.'"

<verse number="19" style="v" />Jacob also gave instructions to the second group, the third, and all the men who followed the herds. He said, "You will say the same thing to Esau when you meet him.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />You must also say, 'Your servant Jacob is coming after us.'" For he thought, "I will appease him with the gifts that I am sending ahead of me. Then later, when I will see him, perhaps he will receive me."

  <verse number="21" style="v" />So the gifts went on ahead of him. He himself stayed that night in the camp.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="22" style="v" />Jacob got up during the night, and took his two wives, his two women servants, and his eleven sons. He sent them across the ford of the Jabbok.

  <verse number="23" style="v" />In this way he sent them across the stream along with all his possessions.

<verse number="24" style="v" />Jacob was left alone, and a man wrestled with him until daybreak.

  <verse number="25" style="v" />When the man saw that he could not defeat him, he struck Jacob's hip. Jacob's hip was dislocated as he wrestled with him.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />The man said, "Let me go, for the dawn is breaking." Jacob said, "I will not let you go unless you bless me."

<verse number="27" style="v" />The man said to him, "What is your name?" Jacob said, "Jacob."

  <verse number="28" style="v" />The man said, "Your name will no longer be called Jacob, but Israel. For you have struggled with God and with men and have prevailed."

<verse number="29" style="v" />Jacob asked him, "Please tell me your name." He said, "Why is it that you ask my name?" Then he blessed him there.

  <verse number="30" style="v" />Jacob called the name of the place Peniel for he said, "I have seen God face to face, and my life is delivered."

<verse number="31" style="v" />The sun rose on Jacob as he passed Peniel. He was limping because of his hip.

  <verse number="32" style="v" />That is why to this day the people of Israel do not eat the ligaments of the hip which are at the hip joint, because the man injured those ligaments while dislocating Jacob's hip.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Jacob looked up and, behold, Esau was coming, and with him were four hundred men. Jacob divided the children among Leah, Rachel, and the two female servants. 

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Then he put the female servants and their children in front, followed by Leah and her children, and followed by Rachel and Joseph last of all.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />He himself went on ahead of them. He bowed toward the ground seven times, until he came near to his brother.

<verse number="4" style="v" />Esau ran to meet him, embraced him, hugged his neck, and kissed him. Then they wept.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />When Esau looked up, he saw the women and the children. He said, "Who are these people with you?" Jacob said, "The children whom God has graciously given your servant."

<verse number="6" style="v" />Then the female servants came forward with their children, and they bowed down.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />Next Leah also and her children came forward and bowed down. Finally Joseph and Rachel came forward and bowed down.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Esau said, "What do you mean by all these groups that I met?" Jacob said, "To find favor in the sight of my master."

<verse number="9" style="v" />Esau said, "I have enough, my brother. Keep what you have for yourself."

  <verse number="10" style="v" />Jacob said, "No, please, if I have found favor in your sight, then accept my gift from my hand, for indeed, I have seen your face, and it is like seeing the face of God, and you have accepted me.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />Please accept my gift that was brought to you, because God has dealt graciously with me, and because I have enough." Thus Jacob urged him, and Esau accepted it.

<verse number="12" style="v" />Then Esau said, "Let us be on our way. I will go before you."

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Jacob said to him, "My master knows that the children are young, and that the sheep and the cattle are nursing their young. If they are driven hard even one day, all the animals will die.

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Please let my master go on ahead of his servant. I will travel more slowly, at the pace of the livestock that are before me, and at the pace of the children, until I come to my master in Seir."

<verse number="15" style="v" />Esau said, "Let me leave with you some of my men who are with me." But Jacob said, "Why do that? My master has already been kind enough to me."

  <verse number="16" style="v" />So Esau that day started on his way back to Seir.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />Jacob traveled to Succoth, built himself a house, and made shelters for his livestock. Therefore the name of the place is called Succoth.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="18" style="v" />When Jacob came from Paddan Aram, he arrived safely at the city of Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan. He camped near the city.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />Then he bought the piece of ground where he had pitched his tent from the sons of Hamor, Shechem's father, for a hundred pieces of silver.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />There he set up an altar and called it El Elohe Israel.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Now Dinah, Leah's daughter whom she bore to Jacob, went out to meet the young women of the land.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Shechem son of Hamor the Hivite, the prince of the land, saw her and he grabbed her, assaulted her, and slept her.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />He was drawn to Dinah, the daughter of Jacob. He loved the young woman and spoke tenderly to her.

<verse number="4" style="v" />Shechem spoke to his father Hamor, saying, "Get this young woman for me as a wife."
