  <verse number="5" style="v" />Now Jacob heard that he had defiled Dinah his daughter. His sons were with his livestock in the field, so Jacob held his peace until they came.

<verse number="6" style="v" />Hamor the father of Shechem went out to Jacob to speak with him.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />The sons of Jacob came in from the field when they heard of the matter. The men were offended. They were very angry because he had disgraced Israel by forcing himself on Jacob's daughter, for such a thing should not have been done.

<verse number="8" style="v" />Hamor spoke with them, saying, "My son Shechem loves your daughter. Please give her to him as a wife.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Intermarry with us, Give your daughters to us, and take our daughters for yourselves.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />You will live with us, and the land will be open to you to live and trade in, and to acquire property."

<verse number="11" style="v" />Shechem said to her father and to her brothers, "Let me find favor in your eyes, and whatever you tell me I will give.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Ask me for as great a bride price and gift as you will, and I will give whatever you say to me, but give me the young woman as a wife."

  <verse number="13" style="v" />The sons of Jacob answered Shechem and Hamor his father with deceit, because Shechem had defiled Dinah their sister.

<verse number="14" style="v" />They said to them, "We cannot do this thing, to give our sister to anyone who is uncircumcised; for that would be a disgrace to us.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />Only on this condition will we agree with you: if you will become circumcised as we are, if every male among you is circumcised.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Then will we give our daughters to you, and we will take your daughters to ourselves, and we will live with you and become one people.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />But if you do not listen to us and become circumcised, then we will take our sister and we will leave."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Their words pleased Hamor and his son Shechem.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />The young man did not delay to do what they said, because he delighted in Jacob's daughter, and because he was the most honored person in all his father's household.

<verse number="20" style="v" />Hamor and Shechem his son went to the gate of their city and spoke with the men of their city, saying,

  <verse number="21" style="v" />"These men are at peace with us, so let them live in the land and trade in it for, really, the land is large enough for them. Let us take their daughters as wives, and let us give them our daughters.

<verse number="22" style="v" />Only on this condition will the men agree to live with us and become one people: if every male among us is circumcised, as they are circumcised.

  <verse number="23" style="v" />Will not their livestock and their property—all their animals be ours? So let us agree with them, and they will live among us."

<verse number="24" style="v" />All the men of the city listened to Hamor and Shechem, his son. Every male was circumcised.

  <verse number="25" style="v" />On the third day, when they were very sore, two of the sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi, Dinah's brothers, each man took his sword and went to the unsuspecting city, and killed all the males.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />They killed Hamor and Shechem, his son, with the edge of the sword. They took Dinah from Shechem's house and left.

<verse number="27" style="v" />The other sons of Jacob came to the dead bodies and looted the city, because the people had defiled their sister.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />They took their flocks, their herds, their donkeys, and everything in the city and in the surrounding fields with 

  <verse number="29" style="v" />all their wealth. All their children and their wives, they captured. They even took everything that was in the houses.

<verse number="30" style="v" />Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, "You have brought trouble on me, to make me stink to the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites and the Perizzites. I am few in number. If they gather themselves together against me and attack me, then I will be destroyed, I and my household."

  <verse number="31" style="v" />But Simeon and Levi said, "Should Shechem have dealt with our sister as with a prostitute?"</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />God said to Jacob, "Arise, go up to Bethel, and stay there. Build an altar there to God, who appeared to you when you fled from Esau your brother."

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Then Jacob said to his household and to all who were with him, "Put away the foreign gods that are among you, purify yourselves, and change your clothes.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Then let us depart and go up to Bethel. I will build an altar there to God, who answered me in the day of my distress, and has been with me wherever I have gone."

<verse number="4" style="v" />So they gave to Jacob all the foreign gods that were in their hand, and the rings that were in their ears. Jacob buried them under the oak that was near Shechem.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />As they traveled, God made panic to fall on the cities that were around them, so those people did not pursue the sons of Jacob.

<verse number="6" style="v" />So Jacob arrived at Luz (that is, Bethel), which is in the land of Canaan, he and all the people who were with him.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />He built an altar there and called the place El Bethel, because there God had revealed himself to him, when he was fleeing from his brother.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Deborah, Rebekah's nurse, died. She was buried down from Bethel under the oak tree, so it was called Allon Bacuth.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="9" style="v" />When Jacob came from Paddan Aram, God appeared to him again and blessed him.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />God said to him, "Your name is Jacob, but your name will no longer be called Jacob. Your name will be Israel." So God called his name Israel.

<verse number="11" style="v" />God said to him, "I am God Almighty. Be fruitful and multiply. A nation and a company of nations will come from you, and kings will be among your descendants.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />The land that I gave to Abraham and Isaac, I will give to you. To your descendants after you I also give the land."

  <verse number="13" style="v" />God went up from him in the place where he spoke with him.

<verse number="14" style="v" />Jacob set up a pillar in the place where God had spoken to him, a pillar of stone. He poured out a drink offering over it and poured oil on it.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />Jacob called the name of the place where God spoke with him, Bethel.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="16" style="v" />They journeyed on from Bethel. While they were still some distance from Ephrath, Rachel went into labor. She had hard labor.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />While she was in hardest labor, the midwife said to her, "Do not be afraid, for now you will have another son."

  <verse number="18" style="v" />As she was dying, with her dying breath she named him Benoni, but his father called him Benjamin.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).

  <verse number="20" style="v" />Jacob set up a pillar upon her grave. It is the marker of Rachel's grave to this day.

<verse number="21" style="v" />Israel traveled on and pitched his tent beyond Migdal Eder.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />While Israel was living in that land, Reuben slept with Bilhah his father's concubine, and Israel heard of it.</para>

<para style="p">Now Jacob had twelve sons.

<verse number="23" style="v" />His sons by Leah were Reuben, Jacob's firstborn, and Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />His sons by Rachel were Joseph and Benjamin.

  <verse number="25" style="v" />His sons by Bilhah, Rachel's female servant, were Dan and Naphtali.

<verse number="26" style="v" />The sons of Zilpah, Leah's female servant, were Gad and Asher. All these were the sons of Jacob who were born to him in Paddan Aram.

  <verse number="27" style="v" />Jacob came to Isaac, his father, in Mamre in Kiriath Arba (the same as Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had lived.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="28" style="v" />Isaac lived for one hundred eighty years.

  <verse number="29" style="v" />Isaac breathed his last and died, and was gathered to his ancestors, an old man full of days. Esau and Jacob, his sons, buried him.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />These were the descendants of Esau (also called Edom).

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Esau took his wives from the Canaanites. These were his wives: Adah the daughter of Elon the Hittite; Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite;

  <verse number="3" style="v" />and Basemath, Ishmael's daughter, sister of Nebaioth.

<verse number="4" style="v" />Adah bore Eliphaz to Esau, and Basemath bore Reuel.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />Oholibamah bore Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These were the sons of Esau who were born to him in the land of Canaan.

<verse number="6" style="v" />Esau took his wives, his sons, his daughters, and all the members of his household, his livestock—all his animals, and all his possessions, which he had gathered in the land of Canaan, and went into a land away from his brother Jacob.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />He did this because their possessions were too many for them to stay together. The land where they had settled could not support them because of their livestock.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />So Esau, also known as Edom, settled in the hill country of Seir.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Following were the descendants of Esau, the ancestor of the Edomites in the hill country of Seir.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />These were the names of Esau's sons: Eliphaz son of Adah, the wife of Esau; Reuel son of Basemath, the wife of Esau.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Timna, a concubine of Eliphaz, Esau's son, bore Amalek. These were the grandsons of Adah, Esau's wife.

<verse number="13" style="v" />These were the sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the grandsons of Basemath, Esau's wife.

  <verse number="14" style="v" />These were the sons of Oholibamah, Esau's wife, who was the daughter of Anah and the granddaughter of Zibeon. She bore to Esau Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="15" style="v" />These were the clans among Esau's descendants: the descendants of Eliphaz, the firstborn of Esau: Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Korah, Gatam, and Amalek. These were the clans descended from Eliphaz in the land of Edom. They were the grandsons of Adah.

<verse number="17" style="v" />These were the clans from Reuel, Esau's son: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, Mizzah. These were the clans descended from Reuel in the land of Edom. They were the grandsons of Basemath, Esau's wife.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />These were the clans of Oholibamah, Esau's wife: Jeush, Jalam, Korah. These are the clans that descended from Esau's wife Oholibamah, daughter of Anah.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />These were the sons of Esau, and these are their clans.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="20" style="v" />These were the sons of Seir the Horite, the inhabitants of the land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,

  <verse number="21" style="v" />Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These were the clans of the Horites, the inhabitants of Seir in the land of Edom.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />The sons of Lotan were Hori and Heman, and Timna was Lotan's sister.

<verse number="23" style="v" />These were the sons of Shobal: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />These were the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah. This is Anah who found the hot springs in the wilderness, as he was pasturing donkeys of Zibeon his father.

<verse number="25" style="v" />These were the children of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />These were the sons of Dishon: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Keran.

  <verse number="27" style="v" />These were the sons of Ezer: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />These were the sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.

<verse number="29" style="v" />These were the clans of the Horites: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, and Anah,

  <verse number="30" style="v" />Dishon, Ezer, Dishan: these were clans of the Horites, according to their clan lists in the land of Seir.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="31" style="v" />These were the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the Israelites:

  <verse number="32" style="v" />Bela son of Beor, reigned in Edom, and the name of his city was Dinhabah.

  <verse number="33" style="v" />When Bela died, then Jobab son of Zerah of Bozrah, reigned in his place.

<verse number="34" style="v" />When Jobab died, and Husham of the land of the Temanites reigned in his place.

  <verse number="35" style="v" />When Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad, who defeated the Midianites in the land of Moab, reigned in his place. The name of his city was Avith.

  <verse number="36" style="v" />When Hadad died, then Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his place.

<verse number="37" style="v" />When Samlah died, then Shaul of Rehoboth by the river reigned in his place.

  <verse number="38" style="v" />When Shaul died, then Baal Hanan son of Achbor reigned in his place.

  <verse number="39" style="v" />When Baal Hanan son of Achbor, died, then Hadar reigned in his place. The name of his city was Pau. His wife's name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, the granddaughter of Me Zahab.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="40" style="v" />These were the names of the heads of clans from Esau's descendants, according to their clans and their regions, by their names:Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,

  <verse number="41" style="v" />Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,

  <verse number="42" style="v" />Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,

  <verse number="43" style="v" />Magdiel, and Iram. These were the clan heads of Edom, according to their settlements in the land they possessed. This was Esau, the father of the Edomites.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Jacob lived in the land where his father was staying, in the land of Canaan.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />These were the events concerning Jacob. Joseph, who was a young man seventeen years old, was guarding the flock with his brothers. He was with the sons of Bilhah and with the sons of Zilpah, his father's wives. Joseph brought an unfavorable report about them to their father.

<verse number="3" style="v" />Now Israel loved Joseph more than all his sons because he was the son of his old age. He made him a beautiful garment.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />His brothers saw that their father loved him more than all his brothers. They hated him and would not speak cordially to him.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="5" style="v" />Joseph dreamed a dream, and he told his brothers about it. They hated him even more.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />He said to them, "Please listen to this dream which I dreamed.

<verse number="7" style="v" />Behold, we were tying bundles of grain in the field and behold, my bundle rose and stood upright, and behold, your bundles came around and bowed down to my bundle."

  <verse number="8" style="v" />His brothers said to him, "Will you really reign over us? Will you actually rule over us?" They hated him even more for his dreams and for his words.

<verse number="9" style="v" />He dreamed another dream and told it to his brothers. He said, "Look, I have dreamed another dream: The sun and the moon and eleven stars bowed down to me."

  <verse number="10" style="v" />He told it to his father just as to his brothers, and his father rebuked him. He said to him, "What is this dream that you have dreamed? Will your mother and I and your brothers actually come to bow down to the ground to you?"

  <verse number="11" style="v" />His brothers were jealous of him, but his father kept the matter in mind.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="12" style="v" />His brothers went to tend their father's flock in Shechem.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Israel said to Joseph, "Are not your brothers tending the flock in Shechem? Come, and I will send you to them." Joseph said to him, "I am ready."

  <verse number="14" style="v" />He said to him, "Go now, see whether it is well with your brothers and well with the flock, and bring me word." So Jacob sent him out of the valley of Hebron, and Joseph went to Shechem.

<verse number="15" style="v" />A certain man found Joseph. Behold, Joseph was wandering in a field. The man asked him, "What do you seek?"

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Joseph said, "I am seeking my brothers. Tell me, please, where they are tending the flock."

  <verse number="17" style="v" />The man said, "They left this place, for I heard them say, 'Let us go to Dothan.'" Joseph went after his brothers and found them at Dothan.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="18" style="v" />They saw him from a distance, and before he came near to them, they plotted against him to kill him.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />His brothers said to one another, "Look, this dreamer is approaching.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />Come now, therefore, let us kill him and cast him into one of the pits. We will say, 'A wild animal has devoured him.' We will see what will become of his dreams."

<verse number="21" style="v" />Reuben heard it and rescued him from their hand. He said, "Let us not take his life."

  <verse number="22" style="v" />Reuben said to them, "Shed no blood. Throw him into this pit that is in the wilderness, but lay no hand upon him"—that he might rescue him out of their hand to bring him back to his father.

<verse number="23" style="v" />It came about that when Joseph reached his brothers, they stripped him of his beautiful garment.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />They took him and threw him into the pit. The pit was empty with no water in it.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="25" style="v" />They sat down to eat bread. They lifted up their eyes and looked, and, behold, a caravan of Ishmaelites was coming from Gilead, with their camels bearing spices and balm and myrrh. They were traveling to carry them down to Egypt.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />Judah said to his brothers, "What profit is it if we kill our brother and cover up his blood?

<verse number="27" style="v" />Come, and let us sell him to the Ishmaelites and not lay our hands upon him. For he is our brother, our flesh." His brothers listened to him.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />The Midianite merchants passed by. His brothers drew Joseph up and lifted him up out of the pit. They sold Joseph to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver. The Ishmaelites carried Joseph into Egypt.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="29" style="v" />Reuben returned to the pit, and, behold, Joseph was not in the pit. He tore his clothes.

  <verse number="30" style="v" />He returned to his brothers and said, "Where is the boy? And I, where will I go?"

<verse number="31" style="v" />They slaughtered a goat and then took Joseph's garment and dipped it into the blood.

  <verse number="32" style="v" />Then they brought it to their father and said, "We found this. Please see whether it is your son's clothing or not."

  <verse number="33" style="v" />Jacob recognized it and said, "It is my son's clothing. A wild animal has devoured him. Joseph has certainly been torn to pieces."

<verse number="34" style="v" />Jacob tore his garments and put sackcloth upon his loins. He mourned for his son many days.

  <verse number="35" style="v" />All his sons and daughters rose up to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted. He said, "Indeed I will go down to sheol mourning for my son." His father wept for him.

  <verse number="36" style="v" />The Midianites sold him in Egypt to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh, the captain of the bodyguard.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />It came about at that time that Judah left his brothers and stayed with a certain Adullamite, whose name was Hirah.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />He met there a daughter of a Canaanite man whose name was Shua. He married her and slept with her.

<verse number="3" style="v" />She became pregnant and had a son. He was named Er.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />She became pregnant again and had a son. She called his name Onan.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />She again had a son and called his name Shelah. It was at Chezib where she gave birth to him.

<verse number="6" style="v" />Judah found a wife for Er, his firstborn. Her name was Tamar.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />Er, Judah's firstborn, was wicked in the sight of Yahweh. Yahweh killed him.

<verse number="8" style="v" />Judah said to Onan, "Sleep with your brother's wife. Do the duty of a brother-in-law to her, and raise up a child for your brother."

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Onan knew that the child would not be his. Whenever he slept with his brother's wife, he spilled the semen on the ground so he would not have a child for his brother.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />What he did was evil in the sight of Yahweh. Yahweh killed him also.

<verse number="11" style="v" />Then Judah said to Tamar, his daughter-in-law, "Remain a widow in your father's house until Shelah, my son, grows up." For he thought, "Lest he also die like his brothers." Tamar left and lived in her father's house.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="12" style="v" />After a long time, Shua's daughter, the wife of Judah, died. Judah was comforted and went up to his sheepshearers at Timnah, he and his friend Hirah the Adullamite.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Tamar was told, "Look, your father-in-law is going up to Timnah to shear his sheep."

  <verse number="14" style="v" />She took off the clothing of her widowhood and covered herself with her veil and wrapped herself. She sat in the gate of Enaim, which is by the road to Timnah. For she saw that Shelah had grown up but she had not been given to him as a wife.

<verse number="15" style="v" />When Judah saw her he thought that she was a prostitute because she had covered her face.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />He went to her by the road and said, "Come, please let me sleep with you"—for he did not know that she was his daughter-in-law—and she said, "What will you give me so you can sleep with me?"

<verse number="17" style="v" />He said, "I will send you a young goat from the flock." She said, "Will you give me a pledge until you send it?"

  <verse number="18" style="v" />He said, "What pledge can I give you?" And she said, "Your seal and cord, and the staff that is in your hand." He gave them to her and slept with her. She became pregnant by him.

<verse number="19" style="v" />She got up and went away. She took off her veil and put on the clothing of her widowhood.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />Judah sent the young goat from the flock with his friend the Adullamite to receive the pledge from the woman's hand, but he did not find her.

<verse number="21" style="v" />Then the Adullamite asked the men of the place, "Where is the cultic prostitute who was at Enaim by the road?" They said, "There has not been a cultic prostitute here."

  <verse number="22" style="v" />He returned to Judah and said, "I did not find her. Also, the men of the place said, 'There has not been a cultic prostitute here.'"

  <verse number="23" style="v" />Judah said, "Let her keep the things, lest we be put to shame. Indeed, I sent this young goat, but you did not find her."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="24" style="v" />It came about after about three months that it was told to Judah, "Tamar your daughter-in-law has committed prostitution, and indeed, she is pregnant by it." Judah said, "Bring her here and let her be burned."

  <verse number="25" style="v" />When she was brought out, she sent to her father-in-law a message, "By the man who owns these I am pregnant." She said, "Determine please whose these are, the seal and cords and staff."

  <verse number="26" style="v" />Judah recognized them and said, "She is more right than I am, since I did not give her as a wife to Shelah, my son." He did not sleep with her again.

<verse number="27" style="v" />It came about at the time for her to give birth that, behold, twins were in her womb.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />It came about as she was giving birth one put out a hand, and the midwife took a scarlet thread and tied it on his hand and said, "This one came out first."

<verse number="29" style="v" />It came about as he drew back his hand, behold, his brother came out first. The midwife said, "How you have broken out!" And he was named Perez.

  <verse number="30" style="v" />Then his brother came out, who had the scarlet thread upon his hand, and he was named Zerah.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Joseph was brought down to Egypt. Potiphar, an official of Pharaoh who was captain of the guard and an Egyptian, bought him from the Ishmaelites, who had brought him down there.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Yahweh was with Joseph and he became a prosperous man. He lived in the house of his Egyptian master.

<verse number="3" style="v" />His master saw that Yahweh was with him and that Yahweh prospered everything that he did.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />Joseph found favor in his sight. He served Potiphar. Potiphar made Joseph manager over his house, and everything that he possessed, he put under his care.

<verse number="5" style="v" />It came about from the time that he made him manager over his house and over everything he possessed, that Yahweh blessed the Egyptian's house because of Joseph. The blessing of Yahweh was on everything that Potiphar had in the house and in the field.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Potiphar put everything that he had under Joseph's care. He did not have to think about anything except the food that he ate. Now Joseph was handsome and attractive.

<verse number="7" style="v" />It came about after this that his master's wife lusted for Joseph. She said, "Sleep with me."

  <verse number="8" style="v" />But he refused and said to his master's wife, "Look, my master does not pay attention to what I do in the house, and he has put everything that he owns under my care.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />No one is greater in this house than I am. He has not kept back anything from me but you, because you are his wife. How then can I do this great wickedness and sin against God?"

<verse number="10" style="v" />She spoke to Joseph day after day, but he refused to sleep with her or to be with her.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />It came about one day that he went into the house to do his work. None of the men of the house were there in the house.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />She caught him by his clothes and said, "Sleep with me." He left his clothing in her hand, fled, and went outside.

<verse number="13" style="v" />It came about, when she saw that he had left his clothing in her hand and had fled outside,

  <verse number="14" style="v" />that she called to the men of her house and told them, "See, Potiphar has brought in a Hebrew to mock us. He came in to me to sleep with me, and I screamed.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />It came about when he heard me scream, that he left his clothing with me, fled, and went outside."

<verse number="16" style="v" />She set his clothing next to her until his master came home.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />She told him this explanation, "The Hebrew servant whom you brought to us, came in to mock me.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />It came about that when I screamed, he left his clothing with me and fled outside."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="19" style="v" />It came about that, when his master heard the explanation his wife told him, "This is what your servant did to me," he became very angry.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />Joseph's master took him and put him in prison, the place where the king's prisoners were confined. He was there in the prison.

<verse number="21" style="v" />But Yahweh was with Joseph and showed covenant faithfulness to him. He gave him favor in the sight of the prison warden.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />The prison warden gave into Joseph's hand all the prisoners who were in the prison. Whatever they did there, Joseph was in charge of it.

  <verse number="23" style="v" />The prison warden did not worry about anything that was in his hand, because Yahweh was with him. Whatever he did, Yahweh prospered.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />It came about that after these things, the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt offended their master, the king of Egypt.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Pharaoh was angry with his two officials, the chief cupbearer and the chief baker.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />He put them in custody in the prison of the captain of the guard, in the same prison where Joseph was confined.

<verse number="4" style="v" />The captain of the guard assigned Joseph to be their servant. They remained in custody for some time.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />Both of them dreamed a dream—the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt who were confined in the prison—each man had his own dream in the same night, and each dream had its own interpretation.

<verse number="6" style="v" />Joseph came to them in the morning and saw them. Behold, they were sad.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />He asked Pharaoh's officials who were with him in custody in his master's house, saying, "Why do you look so sad today?"

  <verse number="8" style="v" />They said to him, "We have both dreamed a dream and no one can interpret it." Joseph said to them, "Do not interpretations belong to God? Tell me, please."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="9" style="v" />The chief cupbearer told his dream to Joseph. He said to him, "In my dream, behold, a vine was in front of me.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />In the vine were three branches. As it budded, its blossoms came out and the clusters of grapes ripened.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />Pharaoh's cup was in my hand. I took the grapes and squeezed them into Pharaoh's cup, and I placed the cup into Pharaoh's hand."

<verse number="12" style="v" />Joseph said to him, "This is the interpretation of it. The three branches are three days.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Within three days Pharaoh will raise your head and restore you to your office. You will put Pharaoh's cup into his hand, just as when you were his cupbearer.

<verse number="14" style="v" />But think of me when it goes well with you, and please show kindness to me. Mention me to Pharaoh and bring me out of this prison.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />For indeed I was abducted out of the land of the Hebrews. Here also have I done nothing that they should put me in this dungeon."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="16" style="v" />When the chief baker saw that the interpretation was favorable, he said to Joseph, "I also had a dream, and, behold, three baskets of bread were on my head.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />In the top basket there were all kinds of baked goods for Pharaoh, but the birds ate them out of the basket on my head."

<verse number="18" style="v" />Joseph answered and said, "This is the interpretation. The three baskets are three days.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />Within three days Pharaoh will lift up your head from you and will hang you on a tree. The birds will eat your flesh off you."

<verse number="20" style="v" />It came about on the third day that it was Pharaoh's birthday. He made a feast for all his servants. He paid special attention to the chief cupbearer and the chief baker, more than to all his other servants.

  <verse number="21" style="v" />He restored the chief cupbearer to his responsibility, and he put the cup into Pharaoh's hand again.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />But he hanged the chief baker, just as Joseph had interpreted to them.

  <verse number="23" style="v" />Yet the chief cupbearer did not remember to help Joseph. Instead, he forgot about him.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />It came about at the end of two full years that Pharaoh had a dream. Behold, he stood by the Nile.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Behold, seven cows came up out of the Nile, desirable and fat, and they grazed in the reeds.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Behold, seven other cows came up after them out of the Nile, undesirable and thin. They stood by the other cows on the bank of the river.

<verse number="4" style="v" />Then the undesirable and thin cows ate the seven desirable and fat cows. Then Pharaoh woke up.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />Then he slept and dreamed a second time. Behold, seven heads of grain came up on one stalk, wholesome and good.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Behold, seven heads, thin and scorched by the east wind, sprouted up after them.

<verse number="7" style="v" />The thin heads swallowed up the seven wholesome and full heads. Pharaoh woke up, and, behold, it was a dream.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />It came about in the morning that his spirit was troubled. He sent and called for all the magicians and wise men of Egypt. Pharaoh told them his dreams, but there was no one who could interpret them to Pharaoh.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Then the chief cupbearer said to Pharaoh, "Today I am thinking about my offenses.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />Pharaoh was angry with his servants, and put me in custody in the house of the captain of the guard, the chief baker and me.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />We dreamed a dream the same night, he and I. We dreamed each man according to the interpretation of his dream.

<verse number="12" style="v" />There was with us there a young Hebrew man, a servant of the captain of the guard. We told him and he interpreted for us our dreams. He interpreted for each of us according to his dream.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />It came about as he interpreted for us, so it happened. Pharaoh restored me to my post, but the other one he hanged."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Then Pharaoh sent and called for Joseph. They quickly took him out of the dungeon. He shaved himself, changed his clothes, and came in to Pharaoh.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />Pharaoh said to Joseph, "I had a dream, but there is no interpreter for it. But I have heard about you, that when you hear a dream you can interpret it."

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Joseph answered Pharaoh, saying, "It is not in me. God will answer Pharaoh with favor."

<verse number="17" style="v" />Pharaoh spoke to Joseph, "In my dream, behold, I stood on the bank of the Nile.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Behold, seven cows came up out of the Nile, fat and desirable, and they grazed among the reeds.

<verse number="19" style="v" />Behold, seven other cows came up after them, weak, very undesirable, and thin. I never saw in all the land of Egypt such undesirableness like them.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />The thin and undesirable cows ate up the first seven fat cows.

  <verse number="21" style="v" />When they had eaten them up, it could not be known that they had eaten them, for they were still as undesirable as before. Then I awoke.

<verse number="22" style="v" />I looked in my dream, and, behold, seven heads came up upon one stalk, full and good.

  <verse number="23" style="v" />Behold, seven more heads, withered, thin and scorched by the east wind, sprang up after them.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />The thin heads swallowed up the seven good heads. I told these dreams to the magicians, but there was none that could explain it to me."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="25" style="v" />Joseph said to Pharaoh, "The dreams of Pharaoh are the same. What God is about to do, he has declared to Pharaoh.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good heads are seven years. The dreams are the same.

<verse number="27" style="v" />And the seven thin and undesirable cows that came up after them are seven years, and also the seven thin heads scorched by the east wind will be seven years of famine.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />That is the thing which I spoke to Pharaoh. What God is about to do he has revealed to Pharaoh.

  <verse number="29" style="v" />Look, seven years of great abundance will come throughout all the land of Egypt.

<verse number="30" style="v" />Seven years of famine will come after them, and all the abundance will be forgotten in the land of Egypt, and the famine will devastate the land.

  <verse number="31" style="v" />The abundance will not be remembered in the land because of the famine that will follow, for it will be very severe.

  <verse number="32" style="v" />That the dream was repeated to Pharaoh is because the matter has been established by God, and God will soon do it.

<verse number="33" style="v" />Now let Pharaoh look for a man discerning and wise, and put him over the land of Egypt.

  <verse number="34" style="v" />Let Pharaoh do this: let him appoint overseers over the land. Let them take a fifth of the crops of Egypt in the seven abundant years.

<verse number="35" style="v" />Let them gather all the food of these good years that are coming. Let them store up grain under the authority of Pharaoh for food in the cities. Let them guard it.

  <verse number="36" style="v" />The food will be a supply for the land for the seven years of famine which will be in the land of Egypt. In this way the land will not be devastated by the famine."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="37" style="v" />This advice was good in the eyes of Pharaoh and in the eyes of all his servants.

  <verse number="38" style="v" />Pharaoh said to his servants, "Can we find such a man as this, in whom is the Spirit of God?"

<verse number="39" style="v" />So Pharaoh said to Joseph, "Since God has shown you all this, there is none so discerning and wise as you.

  <verse number="40" style="v" />You will be over my house, and according to your word will all my people be ruled. Only in the throne will I be greater than you."

  <verse number="41" style="v" />Pharaoh said to Joseph, "See, I have put you over all the land of Egypt."

<verse number="42" style="v" />Pharaoh took off his signet ring from his hand and put it upon Joseph's hand. He clothed him with clothes of fine linen, and put a gold chain on his neck.

  <verse number="43" style="v" />He had him ride in the second chariot which he possessed. Men shouted before him, "Bend the knee." Pharaoh put him over all the land of Egypt.

<verse number="44" style="v" />Pharaoh said to Joseph, "I am Pharaoh, and apart from you, no man will lift his hand or his foot in all the land of Egypt."

  <verse number="45" style="v" />Pharaoh called Joseph's name "Zaphenath Paneah." He gave him Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On, as a wife. Joseph's authority was over all Egypt.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="46" style="v" />Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh, king of Egypt. Joseph went out from the presence of Pharaoh, and went throughout all the land of Egypt.

  <verse number="47" style="v" />In the seven bountiful years the land produced abundantly.

<verse number="48" style="v" />He gathered up all the food of the seven years that was in the land of Egypt and put the food in the cities. He put into each city the food from the fields that surrounded it.

  <verse number="49" style="v" />Joseph stored up grain like the sand of the sea, so much that he stopped counting, because it was beyond counting.

<verse number="50" style="v" />Joseph had two sons before the years of famine came, whom Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On, bore to him.

  <verse number="51" style="v" />Joseph called the name of his firstborn Manasseh, for he said, "God has made me forget all my trouble and all my father's household."

  <verse number="52" style="v" />He called the name of the second son Ephraim, for he said, "God has made me fruitful in the land of my affliction."

<verse number="53" style="v" />The seven years of abundance that was in the land of Egypt came to an end.

  <verse number="54" style="v" />The seven years of famine began, as Joseph had said. There was famine in all lands, but in all the land of Egypt there was food.

<verse number="55" style="v" />When all the land of Egypt was famished, the people loudly called on Pharaoh for food. Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians, "Go to Joseph and do what he says."

  <verse number="56" style="v" />The famine was over all the face of the whole land. Joseph opened all the storehouses and sold to the Egyptians. The famine was severe in the land of Egypt.

  <verse number="57" style="v" />All the earth was coming to Egypt to buy grain from Joseph, because the famine was severe in all the earth.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Now Jacob became aware that there was grain in Egypt. He said to his sons, "Why do you look at one another?"

  <verse number="2" style="v" />He said, "See here, I have heard that there is grain in Egypt. Go down there and buy for us from there so we may live and not die."

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Joseph's ten brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />But Benjamin, Joseph's brother, Jacob did not send with his brothers, for he said, "Lest harm may perhaps happen to him."

<verse number="5" style="v" />The sons of Israel came to buy among those who came, for the famine was in the land of Canaan.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Now Joseph was the governor over the land. He was the one who sold to all the people of the land. Joseph's brothers came and bowed down to him with their faces to the ground.

<verse number="7" style="v" />Joseph saw his brothers and recognized them, but he disguised himself to them and spoke harshly with them. He said to them, "Where have you come from?" They said, "From the land of Canaan to buy food."

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Joseph recognized his brothers, but they did not recognize him.

<verse number="9" style="v" />Joseph remembered the dreams that he had had about them. He said to them, "You are spies. You came to see the undefended parts of the land."

  <verse number="10" style="v" />They said to him, "No, my master. Your servants have come to buy food.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />We are all one man's sons. We are honest men. Your servants are not spies."

<verse number="12" style="v" />He said to them, "No, you have come to see the undefended parts of the land."

  <verse number="13" style="v" />They said, "We your servants are twelve brothers, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan. See, the youngest is this day with our father, and one brother is no longer alive."

<verse number="14" style="v" />Joseph said to them, "It is what I said to you; you are spies.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />By this you will be tested. By the life of Pharaoh, you will not leave here, unless your youngest brother comes here.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Send one of yourselves and let him get your brother. You will remain in prison, that your words may be tested, whether there is truth in you. ."

  <verse number="17" style="v" />He put them all in custody for three days.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Joseph said to them on the third day, "Do this and live, for I fear God.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />If you are honest men, let one of your brothers be confined in this prison, but you go, carry grain for the famine of your houses.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />Bring your youngest brother to me so your words will be verified and you will not die." So they did so.

<verse number="21" style="v" />They said to one another, "We are truly guilty concerning our brother in that we saw the distress of his soul when he pleaded with us and we would not listen. Therefore this distress has come upon us."

  <verse number="22" style="v" />Reuben answered them, "Did I not tell you, 'Do not sin against the boy,' but you would not listen? Now, see, his blood is required of us."

<verse number="23" style="v" />They did not know that Joseph understood them, for there was an interpreter between them.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />He turned from them and wept. He returned to them and spoke to them. He took Simeon from among them and bound him before their eyes.

  <verse number="25" style="v" />Then Joseph commanded his servants to fill his brothers' bags with grain, and to put every man's money back into his sack, and to give them provisions for the journey. It was done for them.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="26" style="v" />The brothers loaded their donkeys with their grain and departed from there.

  <verse number="27" style="v" />As one of them opened his sack to give his donkey feed in the lodging place, he saw his money. Behold, it was in the opening of his sack.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />He said to his brothers, "My money has been put back. Look at it; it is in my sack." And their hearts sank and they turned trembling to one another. They said, "What is this that God has done to us?"

<verse number="29" style="v" />They went to Jacob, their father in the land of Canaan and told him all that had happened to them. They said,

  <verse number="30" style="v" />"The man, the lord of the land, spoke roughly with us and thought that we were spies in the land.

  <verse number="31" style="v" />We said to him, 'We are honest men. We are not spies.

  <verse number="32" style="v" />We are twelve brothers, sons of our father. One is no longer alive, and the youngest is this day with our father in the land of Canaan.'

<verse number="33" style="v" />The man, the lord of the land, said to us, 'By this I will know that you are honest men. Leave one of your brothers with me, take grain for the famine in your houses, and go your way.

  <verse number="34" style="v" />Bring your youngest brother to me. Then I will know that you are not spies, but that you are honest men. Then I will release your brother to you, and you will trade in the land.'"</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="35" style="v" />It came about as they emptied their sacks, that, behold, every man's bag of silver was in his sack. When they and their father saw their bags of silver, they were afraid. 

  <verse number="36" style="v" />Jacob their father said to them, "You have bereaved me of my children. Joseph is no longer alive, Simeon is gone, and you will take Benjamin away. All these things are against me."

<verse number="37" style="v" />Reuben spoke to his father, saying, "You may kill my two sons if I do not bring Benjamin back to you. Put him in my hands, and I will bring him to you again."

  <verse number="38" style="v" />Jacob said, "My son will not go down with you. For his brother is dead and he alone is left. If harm comes to him on the road in which you go, then you will bring down my gray hair with sorrow to sheol."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />The famine was severe in the land.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />It came about when they had eaten the grain that they had brought out of Egypt, their father said to them, "Go again; buy us some food."

<verse number="3" style="v" />Judah told him, "The man solemnly warned us, 'You will not see my face unless your brother is with you.'

  <verse number="4" style="v" />If you send our brother with us, we will go down and buy you food.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />But if you do not send him, we will not go down. For the man said to us, 'You will not see my face unless your brother is with you.'"

<verse number="6" style="v" />Israel said, "Why did you treat me so badly by telling the man that you had another brother?"

  <verse number="7" style="v" />They said, "The man asked details about us and our family. He said, 'Is your father still alive? Do you have another brother?' We answered him according to these questions. How could we have known that he would say, 'Bring your brother down?'"

<verse number="8" style="v" />Judah said to Israel his father, "Send the boy with me. We will rise and go that we may live and not die, both we, you, and also our children.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />I will be a guarantee for him. You will hold me responsible. If I do not bring him back to you and set him before you, then let me bear the blame forever.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />For if we had not delayed, surely by now we would have come back here a second time."

<verse number="11" style="v" />Their father Israel said to them, "If it be so, now do this. Take some of the best products of the land in your bags. Carry down to the man a gift: some balm and honey, spices and myrrh, pistachio nuts and almonds.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Take double money in your hand. The money that was returned in the opening of your sacks, carry again in your hand. Perhaps it was a mistake.

<verse number="13" style="v" />Take also your brother. Rise and go again to the man.

  <verse number="14" style="v" />May God Almighty give you mercy before the man, so that he may release to you your other brother and Benjamin. If I am bereaved of my children, I am bereaved."

  <verse number="15" style="v" />The men took this gift, and in their hand they took double the amount of money, along with Benjamin. They got up and went down to Egypt and stood before Joseph.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="16" style="v" />When Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the steward of his house, "Bring the men into the house, slaughter an animal and prepare it, for the men will eat with me at noon."

  <verse number="17" style="v" />The steward did as Joseph said. He brought the men to Joseph's house.

<verse number="18" style="v" />The men were afraid because they were brought to Joseph's house. They said, "It is because of the money that was returned in our sacks the first time we were brought in, that he may seek an opportunity against us. He might arrest us and take us as slaves, and take our donkeys."

  <verse number="19" style="v" />They approached the steward of Joseph's house, and they spoke to him at the door of the house,

  <verse number="20" style="v" />saying, "My master, we came down the first time to buy food.

<verse number="21" style="v" />It came about, when we reached the lodging place, that we opened our sacks, and, behold, every man's money was in the opening of his sack, our money in full weight. We have brought it back in our hands.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />Other money we have also brought down in our hand to buy food. We do not know who put our money in our sacks."

  <verse number="23" style="v" />The steward said, "Peace be to you, do not fear. Your God and the God of your father must have put your money in your sacks. I received your money." The steward then brought Simeon out to them.

<verse number="24" style="v" />The steward took the men into Joseph's house. He gave them water, and they washed their feet. He gave feed to their donkeys.

  <verse number="25" style="v" />They prepared the gifts for Joseph's coming at noon, for they had heard that they would eat there.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="26" style="v" />When Joseph came home, they brought the gifts which were in their hand into the house, and bowed down before him to the ground.

  <verse number="27" style="v" />He asked them about their welfare and said, "Is your father well, the old man of whom you spoke? Is he still alive?"

<verse number="28" style="v" />They said, "Your servant our father is well. He is still alive." They prostrated and bowed down.

  <verse number="29" style="v" />When he lifted up his eyes he saw Benjamin his brother, his mother's son, and he said, "Is this your youngest brother of whom you spoke to me?" And then he said, "May God be gracious to you, my son."

<verse number="30" style="v" />Joseph hurried to go out of the room, for he was deeply moved about his brother. He sought somewhere to weep. He went to his room and wept there.

  <verse number="31" style="v" />He washed his face and came out. He controlled himself, saying, "Serve the food."

<verse number="32" style="v" />The servants served Joseph by himself and the brothers by themselves. The Egyptians there ate with him by themselves because the Egyptians could not eat bread with the Hebrews, for that is detestable to the Egyptians.

  <verse number="33" style="v" />The brothers sat before him, the firstborn according to his birthright, and the youngest according to his youth. The men were astonished together.

  <verse number="34" style="v" />Joseph sent portions to them from the food in front of him. But Benjamin's portion was five times as much as any of his brothers. They drank and were merry with him.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Joseph commanded the steward of his house, saying, "Fill the men's sacks with food, as much as they can carry, and put every man's money in his sack's opening.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Put my cup, the silver cup, in the sack's opening of the youngest, and also his money for the grain." The steward did as Joseph had said.

<verse number="3" style="v" />The morning dawned, and the men were sent away, they and their donkeys.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />When they were out of the city but were not yet far off, Joseph said to his steward, "Get up, follow after the men, and when you overtake them, say to them, 'Why have you returned evil for good?

  <verse number="5" style="v" />Is this not the cup from which my master drinks, and the cup that he uses for divination? You have done evil, this thing that you have done.'"

<verse number="6" style="v" />The steward overtook them and spoke these words to them.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />They said to him, "Why does my master speak such words as these? Far be it from your servants that they would do such a thing.

<verse number="8" style="v" />Look, the money that we found in our sacks' openings, we brought again to you out of the land of Canaan. How then could we steal out of your master's house silver or gold?

  <verse number="9" style="v" />With whomever of your servants it is found, let him die, and we also will be my master's slaves."

  <verse number="10" style="v" />The steward said, "Now also let it be according to your words. He with whom the cup is found will be my slave, and you others will be innocent."

<verse number="11" style="v" />Then each man hurried and brought his sack down to the ground, and each man opened his sack.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />The steward searched. He began with the oldest and finished with the youngest, and the cup was found in Benjamin's sack.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Then they tore their clothes. Each man loaded his donkey and returned to the city.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Judah and his brothers came to Joseph's house. He was still there, and they bowed before him to the ground.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />Joseph said to them, "What is this that you have done? Do you not know that a man like me practices divination?"

<verse number="16" style="v" />Judah said, "What can we say to my master? What can we speak? Or how can we justify ourselves? God has found out the iniquity of your servants. Look, we are my master's slaves, both we and he also in whose hand the cup was found."

  <verse number="17" style="v" />Joseph said, "Far be it from me that I should do so. The man in whose hand the cup was found, that person will be my slave, but as for you others, go up in peace to your father."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Then Judah came near to him and said, "My master, please let your servant speak a word in my master's ears, and do let your anger burn against your servant, for you are just like Pharaoh.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />My master asked his servants, saying, 'Do you have a father or a brother?'

<verse number="20" style="v" />And we said to my master, 'We have a father, an old man, and a child of his old age, a little one. And his brother is dead, and he alone is left of his mother, and his father loves him.'

  <verse number="21" style="v" />And you said to your servants, 'Bring him down to me that I may see him.'

  <verse number="22" style="v" />And we said to my master, 'The boy cannot leave his father. For if he should leave his father his father would die.'

<verse number="23" style="v" />And you said to your servants, 'Unless your youngest brother comes down with you, you will not see my face again.'

  <verse number="24" style="v" />And it came about when we went up to your servant my father, we told him the words of my master.

  <verse number="25" style="v" />And our father said, 'Go again, buy us some food.'

  <verse number="26" style="v" />And we said, 'We cannot go down. If our youngest brother is with us, then will we go down, for we will not be able to see the man's face unless our youngest brother is with us.'

<verse number="27" style="v" />Your servant my father said to us, 'You know that my wife bore me two sons.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />And the one went out from me and I said, "Surely he is torn in pieces, and I have not seen him since."

  <verse number="29" style="v" />And if you take this one also from me and harm comes to him, you will bring down my gray hair with sorrow to sheol.'

<verse number="30" style="v" />Now, therefore, when I come to your servant my father, and the lad is not with us, since his life is bound up in the boy's life,

  <verse number="31" style="v" />it will come about, when he sees that the boy is not with us that he will die. And your servants will bring down the gray hair of your servant our father with sorrow to sheol.

  <verse number="32" style="v" />For your servant became a guarantee for the boy to my father and said, 'If I do not bring him to you, then I will bear the guilt to my father forever.'

<verse number="33" style="v" />Now therefore, please let your servant stay instead of the boy as slave to my master, and let the boy go up with his brothers.

  <verse number="34" style="v" />For how can I go up to my father if the boy is not with me? I am afraid to see the evil that would come on my father."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Then Joseph could not control himself before all the servants who stood by him. He said loudly, "Everyone must leave me." So no servant stood by him when Joseph made himself known to his brothers.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />He wept loudly, the Egyptians heard it, and the house of Pharaoh heard of it.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Joseph said to his brothers, "I am Joseph. Is my father still alive?" His brothers could not answer him, for they were shocked in his presence.

<verse number="4" style="v" />Then Joseph said to his brothers, "Come near to me, please." They came near. He said, "I am Joseph your brother, whom you sold into Egypt.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />And now do not be grieved or angry with yourselves that you sold me here, for God sent me ahead of you to preserve life.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />For these two years the famine has been in the land, and there are still five years in which there will be neither plowing nor harvest.

<verse number="7" style="v" />God sent me ahead of you to preserve you as a remnant in the earth, and to keep you alive by a great deliverance.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />So now it was not you who sent me here but God, and he has made me a father to Pharaoh, master of all his house, and ruler of all the land of Egypt.

<verse number="9" style="v" />Hurry and go up to my father and say to him, 'This is what your son Joseph says, God has made me master of all Egypt. Come down to me, do not delay.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />You will live in the land of Goshen, and you will be near me, you and your children and your children's children, and your flocks and your herds, and all that you have.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />I will provide for you there, for there are still five years of famine, so that you do not come to poverty, you, your household, and all that you have.'

<verse number="12" style="v" />Look, your eyes see, and the eyes of my brother Benjamin, that it is my mouth that speaks to you.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />You will tell my father about all my power in Egypt, and of all that you have seen. You will hurry and bring my father down here."

<verse number="14" style="v" />He hugged his brother Benjamin's neck and wept, and Benjamin wept on his neck.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />He kissed all his brothers and wept over them. After that his brothers talked with him.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="16" style="v" />The news of the matter was told in Pharaoh's house: "Joseph's brothers have come." It pleased Pharaoh and his servants very much.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />Pharaoh said to Joseph, "Say to your brothers, 'Do this: load your animals and go to the land of Canaan.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Get your father and your households and come to me. I will give you the good of the land of Egypt, and you will eat the fat of the land.'

<verse number="19" style="v" />Now you are commanded, 'Do this, take carts out of the land of Egypt for your children and for your wives. Get your father and come.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />Do not be concerned about your possessions, for the good of all the land of Egypt is yours.'"</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="21" style="v" />The sons of Israel did so. Joseph gave them carts, according to the command of Pharaoh, and gave them provisions for the journey.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />To all of them he gave each man changes of clothing, but to Benjamin he gave three hundred pieces of silver and five changes of clothing.

  <verse number="23" style="v" />For his father he sent this: ten donkeys loaded with the good things of Egypt; and ten female donkeys loaded with grain, bread, and other supplies for his father for the journey.

<verse number="24" style="v" />So he sent his brothers away and they left. He said to them, "See that you do not quarrel on the journey."

  <verse number="25" style="v" />They went up out of Egypt and came to the land of Canaan, to Jacob their father.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />They told him saying "Joseph is still alive, and he is ruler over all the land of Egypt." And his heart was astonished, for he did not believe them.

<verse number="27" style="v" />They told him all the words of Joseph that he had said to them. When Jacob saw the carts that Joseph had sent to carry him, the spirit of Jacob their father revived.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />Israel said, "It is enough. Joseph my son is still alive. I will go and see him before I die."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Israel made his journey with all that he had and went to Beersheba. There he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />God spoke to Israel in a vision at night, saying, "Jacob, Jacob." He said, "Here I am."

  <verse number="3" style="v" />He said, "I am God, the God of your father. Do not fear to go down to Egypt, for there I will make you a great nation.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />I will go down with you into Egypt, and I will surely bring you up again. And Joseph will close your eyes with his own hand."

<verse number="5" style="v" />Jacob rose up from Beersheba. The sons of Israel transported Jacob their father, their children, and their wives, in the carts that Pharaoh had sent to carry him.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />They took their livestock and their possessions that they had accumulated in the land of Canaan. They came into Egypt, Jacob and all his descendants with him.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />He brought with him to Egypt his sons and his sons' sons, his daughters and his sons' daughters, and all his descendants.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="8" style="v" />These were the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt, Jacob and his sons: Reuben, Jacob's firstborn;

  <verse number="9" style="v" />the sons of Reuben Hanoch and Pallu and Hezron and Carmi;

  <verse number="10" style="v" />the sons of Simeon, Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman;

  <verse number="11" style="v" />the sons of Levi Gershon, Kohath, and Merari;

<verse number="12" style="v" />the sons of Judah: Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah,(but Er and Onan had died in the land of Canaan). And the sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />The sons of Issachar were Tola, Puvah, Lob, and Shimron;

  <verse number="14" style="v" />The sons of Zebulun were Sered, Elon, and Jahleel

  <verse number="15" style="v" />These were the sons of Leah whom she bore to Jacob in Paddan Aram, with his daughter Dinah. His sons and his daughters numbered thirty-three.

<verse number="16" style="v" />The sons of Gad were Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Er, Arodi, and Areli.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />The sons of Asher were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah. And Serah was their sister. And the sons of Beriah were Heber and Malchiel

  <verse number="18" style="v" />These were the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban had given to Leah his daughter. These she bore to Jacob—sixteen in all.

<verse number="19" style="v" />The sons of Jacob's wife Rachel were Joseph and Benjamin.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />In Egypt Manasseh and Ephraim were born to Joseph by Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On. 

  <verse number="21" style="v" />The sons of Benjamin were Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />These were the sons of Rachel who were born to Jacob—fourteen in all.

<verse number="23" style="v" />The son of Dan was Hushim.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />The sons of Naphtali were Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.

  <verse number="25" style="v" />These were the sons born to Jacob by Bilhah, whom Laban gave to Rachel his daughter—seven in all.

<verse number="26" style="v" />All the persons who came with Jacob into Egypt, who were his descendants, besides Jacob's sons' wives were sixty-six in all.

  <verse number="27" style="v" />With the two sons of Joseph who were born to him in Egypt, the members of his family who went to Egypt were seventy in all.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="28" style="v" />Jacob sent Judah ahead of him to Joseph to show the way before him to Goshen, and they came to the land of Goshen.

  <verse number="29" style="v" />Joseph prepared his chariot and went up to meet Israel his father in Goshen. He saw him, hugged his neck, and wept on his neck a long time.

  <verse number="30" style="v" />Israel said to Joseph, "Now let me die, since I have seen your face, that you are still alive."

<verse number="31" style="v" />Joseph said to his brothers and to his father's house, "I will go up and tell Pharaoh, saying, 'My brothers and my father's house, who were in the land of Canaan, have come to me.

  <verse number="32" style="v" />The men are shepherds, for they have been keepers of livestock. They have brought their flocks, their herds, and all that they have.'

<verse number="33" style="v" />It will come about, when Pharaoh calls you and asks, 'What is your occupation?'

  <verse number="34" style="v" />that you should say, 'Your servants have been keepers of livestock from our youth until now, both we, and our forefathers.' Do this so that you may live in the land of Goshen, for every shepherd is an abomination to the Egyptians."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Then Joseph went in and told Pharaoh, "My father and my brothers, their flocks, their herds, and all that they own, have arrived from the land of Canaan. See, they are in the land of Goshen."

  <verse number="2" style="v" />He took five of his brothers and introduced them to Pharaoh.

<verse number="3" style="v" />Pharaoh said to his brothers, "What is your occupation?" They said to Pharaoh, "Your servants are shepherds, as our ancestors."

  <verse number="4" style="v" />Then they said to Pharaoh, "We come as temporary residents in the land. There is no pasture for your servants' flocks, because the famine is severe in the land of Canaan. So now, please let your servants live in the land of Goshen."

<verse number="5" style="v" />Then Pharaoh spoke to Joseph, saying, "Your father and your brothers have come to you.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />The land of Egypt is before you. Settle your father and your brothers in the best region, the land of Goshen. If you know any capable men among them, put them in charge of my livestock."

<verse number="7" style="v" />Then Joseph brought in Jacob his father and presented him to Pharaoh. Jacob blessed Pharaoh.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Pharaoh said to Jacob, "How long have you lived?"

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Jacob said to Pharaoh, "The years of my travels are a hundred and thirty. The years of my life have been few and painful. They have not been as long as those of my ancestors." 

  <verse number="10" style="v" />Then Jacob blessed Pharaoh and went out from his presence.

<verse number="11" style="v" />Then Joseph settled his father and his brothers. He gave them a territory in the land of Egypt, the best of the land, in the land of Rameses, as Pharaoh had commanded.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Joseph provided food for his father, his brothers, and all his father's household, according the number of their dependents.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Now there was no food in all the land; for the famine was severe. The land of Egypt and the land of Canaan wasted away because of the famine.

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Joseph gathered all the money that was in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan, by selling grain to the inhabitants. Then Joseph brought the money to Pharaoh's palace.

<verse number="15" style="v" />When all the money of the lands of Egypt and Canaan was spent, all the Egyptians came to Joseph saying, "Give us food! Why should we die in your presence because our money is gone?"

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Joseph said, "If your money is gone, bring your livestock and I will give you food in exchange for your livestock."

  <verse number="17" style="v" />So they brought their livestock to Joseph. Joseph gave them food in exchange for the horses, for the flocks, for the herds, and for the donkeys. He fed them with bread in exchange for all their livestock that year.

<verse number="18" style="v" />When that year was ended, they came to him the next year and said to him, "We will not hide from my master that our money is all gone, and the herds of cattle are my master's. There is nothing left in the sight of my master, except our bodies and our land.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />Why should we die before your eyes, both we and our land? Buy us and our land in exchange for food, and we and our land will be servants to Pharaoh. Give us seed that we may live and not die, and that the land may not become desolate."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="20" style="v" />So Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh. For every Egyptian sold his field, because the famine was very severe. In this way, the land became Pharaoh's.

  <verse number="21" style="v" />As for the people, he made them slaves from one end of Egypt's border to the other end.

  <verse number="22" style="v" />It was only the land of the priests that Joseph did not buy, because the priests were given an allowance. They ate from the allotment which Pharaoh gave them. Therefore they did not sell their land.

<verse number="23" style="v" />Then Joseph said to the people, "See, I have bought you and your land today for Pharaoh. Now here is seed for you, and you will plant the land.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />At the harvest, you must give a fifth to Pharaoh, and four parts will be your own, for seed of the field and for food for your households and your children."

<verse number="25" style="v" />They said, "You have saved our lives. May we find favor in your eyes. We will be Pharaoh's servants."

  <verse number="26" style="v" />So Joseph made it a statute which is in effect in the land of Egypt to this day, that one fifth belongs to Pharaoh. Only the land of the priests did not become Pharaoh's.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="27" style="v" />So Israel lived in the land of Egypt, in the land of Goshen. His people gained possessions there. They were fruitful and multiplied greatly.

  <verse number="28" style="v" />Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years, so the years of Jacob's life were one hundred forty-seven years.

<verse number="29" style="v" />When the time approached for Israel to die, he called his son Joseph and said to him, "If now I have found favor in your sight, put your hand under my thigh, and show me faithfulness and trustworthiness. Please do not bury me in Egypt.

  <verse number="30" style="v" />When I sleep with my fathers, you will carry me out of Egypt and bury me in my forefathers' burial place." Joseph said, "I will do as you have said."

  <verse number="31" style="v" />Israel said, "Swear to me," and Joseph swore to him. Then Israel bowed down at the head of his bed.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />It came about after these things, that one said to Joseph, "Look, your father is sick." So he took with him his two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />When Jacob was told, "Look, your son Joseph has arrived to see you," Israel gathered strength and sat up in bed.

<verse number="3" style="v" />Jacob said to Joseph, "God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in the land of Canaan. He blessed me

  <verse number="4" style="v" />and said to me, 'Behold, I will make you fruitful, and multiply you. I will make of you an assembly of nations. I will give this land to your descendants as an everlasting possession.'

<verse number="5" style="v" />And now your two sons, who were born to you in the land of Egypt before I came to you into Egypt, they are mine. Ephraim and Manasseh will be mine, just as Reuben and Simeon are mine.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />The children you have after them will be yours; they will be listed under the names of their brothers in their inheritance.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />But as for me, when I came from Paddan, to my sorrow Rachel died in the land of Canaan on the way, while there was still some distance to go to Ephrath. I buried her there on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem)."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="8" style="v" />When Israel saw Joseph's sons, he said, "Whose are these?"

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Joseph said to his father, "They are my sons, whom God has given me here." Israel said, "Bring them to me, that I may bless them."

  <verse number="10" style="v" />Now Israel's eyes were failing because of his age, so he could not see. So Joseph brought them near to him, and he kissed them and embraced them.

<verse number="11" style="v" />Israel said to Joseph, "I never expected to see your face again, but God has even allowed me to see your children."

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Joseph brought them out from between Israel's knees, and then he bowed with his face to the earth.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Joseph took them both, Ephraim in his right hand toward Israel's left hand, and Manasseh in his left hand toward Israel's right hand, and brought them close to him.

<verse number="14" style="v" />Israel reached out with his right hand and laid it upon Ephraim's head, who was the younger, and his left hand upon Manasseh's head. He crossed his hands, for Manasseh was the firstborn.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />Israel blessed Joseph, saying, </para>

<para style="q1">"The God before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked, </para>

<para style="q1">the God who has cared for me to this day,</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="16" style="v" />the angel who has protected me from all harm, may he bless these boys. </para>

<para style="q1">May my name be named in them, and the name of my fathers Abraham and Isaac. </para>

<para style="q1">May they grow into a multitude on the earth."

<verse number="17" style="v" />When Joseph saw his father place his right hand upon the head of Ephraim, it displeased him. He took his father's hand to move it from Ephraim's head to Manasseh's head.

<verse number="18" style="v" />Joseph said to his father, "Not so, my father; for this is the firstborn. Put your right hand upon his head."

<verse number="19" style="v" />His father refused and said, "I know, my son, I know. He also will become a people, and he also will be great. Yet his younger brother will be greater than he, and his descendants will become a multitude of nations."

<verse number="20" style="v" />Israel blessed them that day with these words,</para>

<para style="q1">"The people of Israel will pronounce blessings by your names saying, </para>

<para style="q1">'May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh'." In this way, Israel put Ephraim before Manasseh.

<verse number="21" style="v" />Israel said to Joseph, "See, I am about to die, but God will be with you, and will bring you back to the land of your fathers.

<verse number="22" style="v" />To you, as one who is above your brothers, I give the mountain slope that I took from the Amorites with my sword and my bow."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Then Jacob called for his sons, and said: </para>

<para style="q1">"Gather yourselves together, that I may tell you what will happen to you inthe future.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="2" style="v" />Assemble yourselves and listen, you sons of Jacob. Listen to Israel, your father.</para>

<para style="q2">

<verse number="3" style="v" />Reuben, you are my firstborn, my might, and the beginning of my strength,</para>

<para style="q1">outstanding in dignity, and outstanding in power.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="4" style="v" />Uncontrollable as rushing water, you will not have the preeminence,</para>

<para style="q1">because you went up to your father's bed.</para>

<para style="q1">Then you defiled it; you went up to my couch.</para>

<para style="q2">

<verse number="5" style="v" />Simeon and Levi are brothers. Weapons of violence are their swords.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="6" style="v" />O my soul, do not come into their council; do not join in their meetings, for my heart has too much honor for that. </para>
